Review Recent progress on design and applications of transition metal chalcogenide-associated electrocatalysts for the overall water splitting Hui Su a b 1 Jing Jiang a b 1 Shaojia Song c Bohan An a b Ning Li a b Yangqin Gao a b Lei Ge a b * a State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, College of New Energy and Materials, China University of Petroleum Beijing, Beijing 102249, China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing College of New Energy and Materials China University of Petroleum Beijing Beijing 102249 China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, College of New Energy and Materials, China University of Petroleum Beijing, Beijing 102249, China b Department of Materials Science and Engineering, College of New Energy and Materials, China University of Petroleum Beijing, Beijing 102249, China Department of Materials Science and Engineering College of New Energy and Materials China University of Petroleum Beijing Beijing 102249 China Department of Materials Science and Engineering, College of New Energy and Materials, China University of Petroleum Beijing, Beijing 102249, China c College of Science, China University of Petroleum Beijing, Beijing 102249, China College of Science China University of Petroleum Beijing Beijing 102249 China College of Science, China University of Petroleum Beijing, Beijing 102249, China * Corresponding author 1 Contributed equally to this work. Electrochemical hydrogen evolution via water splitting has been regarded as a highly promising technique for fossil-fuel substitution in the future to avoid environmental pollution and energy waste. As half of the water splitting reaction, the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is the major obstacle because of the sluggish kinetics of the complex reaction. It is imperative and urgent to develop highly efficient, low cost and earth-abundant electrocatalysts to overcome the sluggish kinetics issue. Among the various non-noble-metal-based electrocatalysts, transition metal chalcogenide (TMS) associated materials have been exploited as potential candidates for the past few years due to their excellent electrochemical performance and unique internal structure. In this review, we have summarized the recent advances of transition metal sulfides (TMSs) for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), OER, and overall water splitting, then we have reviewed several modified strategies from the perspective of their functional concepts to synthesis methods, characterization techniques, catalytic mechanisms and performances. Finally, the existing deficiencies, challenges and future development directions of TMSs in OER, HER, and overall water splitting process are further discussed and summarized. Graphical Abstract The synthesis method and design principle of transition metal sulfide electrocatalytic materials are introduced, and the catalytic mechanism of OER and HER in electrocatalytic water is analyzed, which provides reference for rational design and research of efficient electrocatalysts. Keywords Transition metal chalcogenide Hydrogen evolution reaction Oxygen evolution reaction Water splitting Electrocatalysis 1 Introduction As we well known, with the development of economics and population, the problem of environmental pollution and energy shortage have become increasingly severe [1–17]. To mitigate the issues, it is urgent to find new energy sources to replace carbon-based energy in order to save resources and protect the environment [7,18–23]. Hydrogen, as one of the most optimal substitutes for fossil fuels due to the high gravimetric energy density and zero environmental pollution, has attracted the attention of researchers in the past decades [14,23–34]. Electrochemical water splitting which has a higher conversion efficiency, hydrogen production purity and commercial value, are considered as the optimal way to generate hydrogen compared with other methods [9,35–37]. Overall water splitting systems require a higher reaction cell potential to overcome the sluggish kinetics of the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) process. Therefore, it is very necessary to search for suitable catalysts to reduce the cathode (HER) and anode (OER) reaction overpotential to accelerate hydrogen and oxygen generation efficiently [38–41]. So far, some precious metal materials such as Pt, Pd, Ir, Ru and their alloy compounds have been investigated as HER and OER catalysts due to their excellent electrochemical performance and appropriate adsorption energy of reaction intermediate [39,41–45]. However, the scarcity and high cost of precious metal-based materials limit their wide application. Therefore, it is strongly necessary to exploit low-cost and earth-abundant electrocatalysts. In recent years, research experts have made a lot of efforts toward the exploration of nonnoble-metal-based materials [46,47], which are low-cost, earth-abundant and high-performance, such as transition metal oxides, phosphides [48,49], sulfides [50,51] and nitrides [52,53], etc. Due to their high catalytic performance, tunable electronic structure, and distinctive physicochemical property, TMSs have particularly received a lot of attention for both OER and HER. According to our knowledge, mono-metallic sulfides such as NiS x , CoS x , and MoS2 always function as true active sites with changeable valence electrons in 3d orbitals to demonstrate higher intrinsic activity for overall water splitting. In layered transition metal sulfides, 1TMoS2 of the Mo atomic d orbitals is often represented by MoS2, and this exhibits metallic qualities, which will be more advantageous to improving its electrochemical performance. The base plane and the edge plane, two alternative orientations that both display anisotropy in various ways, are produced by the distinctive layered structure. When x = 1 and y = 2, non-layered M x S y (M = Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, etc.) typically share a pyrite or marcasite structure, with the octahedra in the marcasite structure sharing edges rather than the pyrite structure sharing corners. For each distinct M x S y structure, variations in x and y values are permitted, and a variety of sulfides, including CoS, CoS2, Co3S4, Co7S6, and Co9S8, can develop. While (Fe, Co, and Ni) M3S2 exhibits inherent metallic behavior due to the presence of a continuous conductive network connected by M-M bonds in the crystal structure, the composition of non-layered M x S y in metal sulfides, MS2, is often an insulator. However, there is still a long way to achieve commercial applications. Therefore, in recent years, researchers have made great efforts to improve the electrochemical performance and stability of binary metal sulfides. For example, conducting different modification strategies, including combination engineering, vacancy designing and doping decoration [54–56]. Wu et al. [57] reported the bifunctional electrode of Ni x Co3–x S/Ni3S2 for overall water splitting, which has lower potential and remarkable stability compared with single Ni x Co3–x S and Ni3S2. Li et al. [58] demonstrated that introducing S vacancies on the surface of MoS2 can act as the new active sites to stimulate the intrinsic catalytic activity by experiments combination theoretical calculations. Luo et al. [59] prepared Mo-Ni3S2/NF flower clusters by partially phosphating method, and the prominent electrocatalytic activity mainly benefited from the electronic structure reorganization. In a word, most of the previous studies mainly concentrate upon material-preparation-perfor- mance connection of HER/OER samples, while fabricating measures for catalysts on account of electron orbitals occupying and reaction mechanisms operating conditions are rare emphasized, which requires complete exploration from the viewpoint of commercial applications. The electrocatalytic performance of HER is significantly influenced by S atoms and S vacancies exposed at the edge or base plane of TMS, which may be seen as the physical manifestation of the interaction of S atoms. The S atom near the edge may be the active site. The improvement of OER activity is also aided by the S vacancy on the lamellar metal disulfide base plane. The S vacancy, on the one hand, has the ability to alter the coordination environment of nearby metal atoms (low coordination metal atoms are more active and have higher intrinsic electrocatalytic activity). On the other hand, S vacancy can result in an increase in the number of active centers [60,61]. OER is more complicated than HER because it requires more intermediates (OH* and OOH*) throughout the reaction process. The repulsion between the S 3p and O 2p orbitals is what prevents the electronegative S atoms in TMS from coordinating OH* with metal atoms. The production of the OOH* intermediate may also be aided by delocalized electrons of the S atom, and this 3p-2p repulsion may speed up further oxidation of the intermediate. Because of the conversion of TMS to transition metal hydrogen (oxygen) oxides during OER, TMS typically functions as a precatalyst [62,63]. As a result, when TMS functions as an electrocatalyst, the metal atom serves as the primary active site to enhance the material's catalytic performance, and the S atom is crucial to the reaction process. The S atom speeds up the catalytic material's transition to the transition metal hydrogen (oxygen) oxide during the anodic reaction. S atoms that are exposed at the edge of the cathodic reaction can, in certain circumstances, serve as active sites for H adsorption and desorption. Metal atoms are active sites, and S vacancies can increase the activity by inducing additional active sites and coordinating metal atoms close to the reaction center. Transition metal sulfide materials, involving transition metal-based materials and their derivative samples, have been developed as high performance catalysts, which display outstanding properties such as favorable electrical conductivity, appropriate d-band center, and specific catalytic properties, in the photo- and electro-catalytic process for water splitting, supercapacitors, lithium-ion batteries and CO2 reduction. Recently, transition metal-based compounds have been explored and reviewed by many researchers. For example, Huang et al. [48] reviewed strategies to optimize the electrocatalytic activity of TMCs. Particular emphasis is placed on promising strategies for tuning the electronic structure of TMCs through surface vacancies/defects, heteroatom doping, strain modulation, phase transitions, and heterostructure engineering. Peng et al. [49] reviewed recent advances in chemical properties, synthesis methods, catalytic performance evaluation, and improvement strategies. Sun et al. [50] summarize the recently reported engineering of water decomposition catalysts based on transition metal compounds with multiple anionic, cationic, and zero-valent elements. The above reviews summarized the electrocatalytic overall water splitting by transition metal sulfides from different perspectives. In addition, the synthesis method and mechanism, the catalysts of elements V, W, and Mo, and the basic synthesis methods should also be systematically summarized. In this review, we give a comprehensive summary concentrating on the recent progress in TMSs as high-efficiency electrocatalysts for the HER, OER and overall water splitting. In the beginning, the basic conception, preparation methods of those TMSs-based electrocatalysts are systematically summarized. Then, the electronic structures, crystal structures, several modification methods and properties of TMSs-based electrocatalysts, especially for Mo, W, Ni, Co elements are highlighted in discussion, regarding synthesis strategies and electrocatalysts performances of corresponding electrocatalysts are also emphasized due to the well-accepted concept with Ni and Co as real catalytic active sites. Finally, some suggestions on the existent shortcomings and future development perspectives for exploiting new TMSs with the superior electro-catalytic property are generalized. 2 Fundamental concepts of overall water splitting The history of the development of electrocatalytic water splitting can be traced back to 1789. Deiman and Troostwijk put gold electrodes in Leiden bottles and observed bubbles. In 1800, the physicist Volta invented the volt battery, which was then applied to the field of electrolysis of water. In 1833, Faraday proposed Faraday's law of electrolysis, which became a milestone in the history of water splitting development. In 1869, Gramme invented the direct-current generator, which accelerated the development of hydrogen production technology by electrolysis of water. In 1888, Lachinov further explored the technology of industrial-grade electrolysis of water to generate hydrogen and oxygen. Since then, the hydropower industry has gradually grown and matured. Since the 20th century, various kinds of water electrolytic cells have been prepared under the influence of the vigorous development of water splitting technology. Typically, atmospheric pressure electrolytic cells were manufactured in 1958 by Harbin Machine Joint Factory and Shanghai New Machine Factory. Several DQ and ZDQ (DQ, ZDQ represents the model of the pressurized hydrolysis unit respectively) pressure hydrolyzing devices were developed in 1980 by 718 Research Institute of China State Shipbuilding Corporation [64,65]. 2.1 HER/OER mechanism No matter in acidic or alkaline electrolyte, the HER reaction is a two-electron transfer process on the catalyst surface that follows either Volmer-Heyrovsky or Volmer-Tafel mechanisms [26,66–69]. Firstly, one electron reacts with a proton which is adsorbed on the catalytic sites to form an adsorbed hydrogen atom (H*) on the surface of the electrocatalyst (Volmer step in acidic media). Subsequently, H2 is formed by either the Heyrovsky reaction (the second electron reacts with the H* which combines with another diffused proton) or the Tafel reaction (two neighboring H* atoms react directly on the surface of the electrode to produce H2). Among them, H* is provided by easily getatable hydronium ions (H3O + ). It is worth noting that the cleavage of the strong covalent H–O–H bond is a prerequisite for H* adsorption in an alkaline or neutral environment, which directly lead to slower reaction kinetics of HER in the Volmer step compared to the acidic media. Typically, experiments have observed that the dissociation rate of Pt in an acidic medium is at least two orders of magnitude higher than that in alkaline conditions due to the advantageous reaction kinetics for Pt [66,70,71]. Therefore, during the past ten years, research professionals have focused their efforts on enhancing HER's performance in alkaline environments. In addition to the useful theoretical calculations, the Tafel slope calculation also provides a useful way to represent the HER mechanism. Where the rate-determining steps (RDS) of the Tafel, Heyrovsky, and Volmer are represented, respectively, by values of the Tafel slop of 30, 40, and 120 mV dec−1. As a result, experts largely concur that the Tafel slope can be used to assess the RDS and response route of HER [72]. Normally, HER reactions tend to occur on the surface of electrocatalytic materials, and the reaction process involves the formation of an H intermediate H*. Therefore, for metal catalysts, the free energy of hydrogen adsorption (ΔG H*) has been acted as an important criterion to evaluate the activities of HER catalysts. As shown in (Fig. 1(b) ), the concept of the classic hydrogen evolution reaction volcano diagram was proposed for the first time by Trasatti in 1972 [73]. It is unachievable to establish the quantitative relationship between the adsorption energy and the reaction rate directly because of the lack of direct technology to measure the surface bond energy. Utilized computational quantum chemistry provides a rational and scientific way to determine G H* values using density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The OER/HER intrinsic reaction mechanism can be discovered using DFT calculations, which can also be used to assess the intrinsic activity of catalysts [74]. Additionally, DFT calculations have delivered precise information for electrochemical processes at the atomistic level as a result of the advancement and continuing improvement of computational methodologies [67,69,75]. The chemical adsorption and desorption of H atoms in HER is a process that is competitive. In order to achieve proton-electron transfer, a good HER catalyst must have the right bond energy to adsorb H*. This ensures that the bond energy is broken and the H2 gas is released promptly. The change in Gibbs free energy of H* adsorbed on the electrocatalyst surface (ΔG H*) can be used to assess H* adsorption and H2 desorption in the HER free energy diagram. Therefore, the value of ΔG H* close to 0 is a prerequisite for choosing an ideal HER catalyst [76,77]. In acidic media, (where * is the active site on the surface of the catalyst.) Volmer: H+ + e− + * → H* Heyrovsky: H+ + e− + H* → H2 Tafel: H* + H* → H2 In alkaline media, (where * is the active site on the surface of catalyst.) Volmer: H2O + e− + * → H* + OH− Heyrovsky: H+ + e− + H* → H2 + OH− Tafel: H* + H* → H2 The HER and OER are the two main half-reactions involved in the electrocatalytic water splitting [78]. Among them, OER is a multi-step intricate reaction process, which mainly includes the adsorption and desorption of some intermediates (HO*, O*, HOO*) by the metal active center, as shown in (Fig. 1(f)). There are two main routes for the generation of oxygen: one is through the direct reaction of two M–O bonds to produce oxygen (the greenway), the other is through the formation of an intermediate M–OOH and subsequent decomposition of the intermediate to produce oxygen (red path) [78,79]. Theoretically, both alkaline and acid electrolytes in the electrocatalytic water splitting reaction require a cell voltage of 1.23 V. However, the required potential is much higher than the theoretical potential of 1.23 V to drive the OER during the realistic conditions, and the value beyond the theoretically required potential is defined as an overpotential. This is mainly attributed to the OER reaction process, it is necessary to overcome the energy barrier of the reaction itself and the various resistance voltage drops in the electrolytic cell, which also means that additional power loss is required and the energy conversion efficiency is reduced. Most electrocatalytic materials face serious stability problems, attributing to the reason that they are easily dissolved in acidic electrolytes under high potential conditions. Compared with acidic electrolytes, these transition metal oxides and sulfides show excellent OER stability and catalytic activity in alkaline electrolytes. In particular, OH− will first be adsorbed to the active sites on the catalyst surface. The adsorbed OH (HO* species) then undergoes subsequent deprotonation to form O*. Next, O* adsorbs another OH− to form a HOO* intermediate in the O–O bond formation step. In the last step of the internal reaction, O2 is formed following the regeneration of the active site through deprotonation of HOO*. Similarly, the OER reaction also occurs on the surface of the electrocatalytic materials. The reaction process involves the formation of a series of intermediates such as OH*, O*, OOH*, denoted as ΔG OH*, ΔG O*, ΔG OOH* and ΔG O2, etc. [80]. The actual energy required for each step of the reaction is equal to the difference between the binding energy of the reaction in this step and the energy of the previous step, denoted as ΔG 1, ΔG 2, ΔG 3 and ΔG 4, respectively, all of those specific values involved also can be calculated by the DFT method. In principle, the rate-determination step can be any of these four reaction steps, then the OER performance of a given catalyst is subject to various internal factors. In particular, ΔG 1 or ΔG 4 seldom act as a step catalyst for determining the potential in most OERs mainly due to the fact that HOO* and HO* are bound to oxygen atoms through a single bond on the catalyst surface, resulting in a relatively difficult H desorption and the corresponding high ΔG value [81]. According to the Sabatier principle, the ideal OER catalyst should have strong enough bond energy to adsorb OH- for the proton-electron transfer process, but not too strong to ensure the desorption of H* and the release of O2. In acidic conditions, (where * is the active site on the surface of the catalyst.) 2H2O → *OH + H2O + H+ + e− *OH + H2O → *O + H2O + H+ + e− *O + H2O → *OOH + H+ + e− *OOH → O2 + H+ + e− In alkaline media, (where * is the active site on the surface of catalyst.) 4OH− → *OH + 3OH− + e− *OH + 3OH− → *O + H2O + 2OH− + e− *O + H2O + 2OH− → *OOH + H2O + OH− + e− *OOH + H2O + OH− → O2 + 2H2O + e− 2.2 Performance evaluation parameters Typical parameter measurements or calculations are indispensable to evaluate various aspects of the HER/OER performance of the target catalyst, including overpotential, initial point position, Tafel slope, turnover frequency, and stability. An accurate understanding of these parameters is conducive to the design of novel and high-performance catalysts. In this section, the basic meaning and content of these parameters are simply discussed and introduced [26,83–85]. 2.2.1 Overpotential (direct evaluation of catalyst activity) HER/OER can occur at 0V/1.23V (relative to reversible hydrogen electrode, RHE) in the ideal condition, extra potential relative to 0V/1.23V is called overpotential (η). In general, the corresponding over-potential of η 10 and η 100 is generally studied during the research process, the voltage required lower means the activity is higher. Among them, η 10 is the premise of commercial application, and η 100 is the evaluation of catalytic activity in practical application. It should be noted that the same test conditions are a prerequisite for the evaluation of catalyst performance through polarization curves, such as the load of the catalyst, the surface area of the catalyst, the difference in the concentration of the electrolyte, and the scanning speed of the electrochemical test [86]. 2.2.2 Tafel slope The Tafel slope can be acted as reacting the kinetic parameters of the HER/OER reaction process to understand the linear relationship between the current density and the overpotential of the catalytic material. In addition, the Tafel slope can reflect the charge transfer capacity (Tafel slope is inversely proportional to the charge transfer coefficient), which means that the lower the Tafel slope, the higher the charge transfer. The Tafel slope can be obtained by calculating the polarization curve and used to evaluate the catalyst activity. Its physical significance is that the overpotential is required to increase the current density of the catalyst by an order of magnitude. The Tafel equation in question is η = blog(j/j 0), where b, j and j 0 are the Tafel slope, overall current, and exchange current density. The slope, as previously mentioned, can also reveal the response pathway and RDS. Better HER/OER performance is indicated by low b and high j 0 values [87,88]. 2.2.3 Exchange current density Exchange current density is a parameter to evaluate the intrinsic activity of the catalyst. It can describe the ability to gain and losing electrons to evaluate the difficulty level of the electrocatalytic process, which involves the H+/OH− adsorption and desorption in electrochemical reactions. It should be noted that the exchange current density should be compared on the same surface and that the exchange current density is connected with the intrinsic properties of the catalyst itself. 2.2.4 Electrochemically active surface area Based on the electrochemical double-layer capacitance of the surface of the catalytic material, electrochemically active specific surface area (ECSA) is a crucial measure to assess the effective active area of a catalyst. The scan rate of the CV curve was used to determine the electrochemical double-layer capacitance value, and the related capacitive current was measured in the Faradaic area. The electrochemical double layer capacitance (C dl) value is equal to the slope of the charge current plot as a function of final scan rate. 2.2.5 Turnover frequency Turnover frequency (TOF) can be expressed as the number of electrochemical reactions in a single active site per unit time. The TOF value is positively proportional to the catalytic activity, which can evaluate the intrinsic activity of the catalyst. The gas generated will affect the reaction of the catalyst in the actual test process due to the hydrogen generated at the interface between the catalyst material and the electrolyte, which is adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst [89,90]. 2.2.6 Stability Stability is also an important parameter to exploration catalyst performance apart from the above parameters. Cyclic voltammetry and current/voltage methods are usually used to explore the long-term stability of catalysts. The range of potential tests is consistent with that of the polarization curve test in the CV test. Stability was evaluated by comparing the coincidence degree of polarization curves before and after the CV cycle. Chronopotentiometry/chronoamperometry test is measured at a given current density/a specific potential at a specific time. Because these parameters are easily affected by certain factors experimental conditions (such as substrate, mass load, electrolyte, ink preparation), it is necessary to ensure that the different catalysts have the same experimental conditions in order to make a fair comparison [91]. 2.3 Overall water splitting When HER and OER occur simultaneously in an electrolytic cell using a two-electrode setup, this is referred to as the entire water splitting as opposed to the single half-reaction HER/OER. Involved is the following reaction equation: In acidic condition, 2H2O – 4e− → O2 + 4H+ 4H+ → 2H2 – 4e− In alkaline media, 4OH− → 2H2O + O2 + 2e− 2H2O + 2e− → H2 + 2OH− The fabrication of high-efficiency (high current density) and stable (thousands of hours) catalysts still faces many setbacks, although the performance of HER/OER electrocatalysts has been greatly improved [92]. First of all, for powder catalysts, it is usually necessary to bond to the surface of the substrate with an adhesive during the test process. Increased electrical resistance will result in poor conductivity. For in-situ synthesized catalysts, the low loading amount will lead to limited active sites, which is not conducive to reaction [93]. Secondly, both the HER and OER reactions involve the escape of gas in the actual operating environment, a large number of bubbles are generated on the surface of the catalyst and cannot be removed in time, forming a large interface resistance [94]. Finally, sulfide is used as a catalyst to undergo long-term oxidation, etching, etc., resulting in damage to the structure, which is not conducive to the stable operation of the material [95]. Therefore, most of the high-efficiency catalysts reported at present are mainly focused on 10 mA m−2, which is far from the practical commercial application (> 500 mA cm−2) [96,97]. 3 Synthesis strategies of transition metal sulfides (TMSs) In recent years, a variety of synthetic techniques have been used to create transition metal sulfides (TMSs) with varying compositions, morphologies, and physicochemical characteristics. Liquid-phase exfoliation (LPE), the hydrothermal/solvothermal process, electrochemical deposition, Ion exchange technology, etc. are typical examples. In order to lay a foundation for the subsequent investigation of additional new sulfides, these techniques will be thoroughly explained in the sections that follow. 3.1 Hydrothermal/solvothermal method The hydrothermal process is a chemical reaction in which the powder is dissolved and recrystallized in a sealed pressurized vessel with water as the solvent [98]. Compared with other fabrication measures, the materials prepared by the hydrothermal method have many advantages, such as complete grain development, small particle size, uniform distribution, lighter particle agglomeration, the use of cheaper raw materials, easy to get suitable crystal shape, etc. Yang et al. [99] proposed a simple and one-pot method for fabrication of MoS2-Ni3S2 heteronanorodes supported by NF (MoS2-Ni3S2 HNRs/NF), which successfully enhanced the HER, OER and overall water splitting performance of MoS2-Ni3S2 HNRs/NF under mild conditions by environmentally friendly and easily available hydrothermal process. As shown in (Fig. 2(a) ), first, one-dimensional NiMoO4 (NF) was generated on the nickel foam in the hydrothermal process at 240 °C, then NiMoO4 has further developed during the sulfuration process at 240 °C due to the anisotropic growth of molybdate and the long-term reaction with thioacetamide (TAA), resulting in the internal Ni3S2-MoS2 nanosheets subtly decorating the surface of the nanorods. Ni3S2 nanorods were uniformly combined with ultra-thin MoS2 nanosheets, which are conducive to the exposure of heterogeneous interfaces and active sites. Finally, MoS2-Ni3S2 electrocatalysts exhibit remarkable activity for HER (98 mV@10 mA cm−2) and OER (249 mV@10 mA cm−2). Interestingly, Peng et al. [100] synthesized hierarchical Co9S8 with nanobelts-like, nanoneedles-like, and nanorhombuses-like morphologies via the hydrothermal reaction of Co(NO3)2 and sodium sulfide ((Fig. 2(b))). Sodium sulfide played an important role in the reaction. The high electrochemical performance is mainly attributed to the unique morphology and porous array structure formed between Co9S8 and WS2, which can achieve a large electrochemical effective surface area, good electrical conductivity and rapid electron migration in the electrolysis process, thus leading to excellent catalytic activities [100]. Because of the ease of control of the reaction process, effective interlayer interface construction can be achieved easily by using reasonable hydrothermal approaches. Huang et al. [101] prepared MoP@MoS2 nanoarrays with interlayer interfaces via a facile hydrothermal approach. During the reaction, the first step hydrothermally reacts (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O to produce MoO3, the second step uses MoO3 and thiourea as precursors to hydrothermally prepare MoS2. Finally, the P-substituted MoS2 interface structure is prepared at high temperatures. The MoS2-MoP/NC heterostructure exhibited an effective enhancement of HER activity compared to other materials in alkaline media, which is even better than commercial Pt/C. Not only that, DFT calculations certify that the interface construction between MoS2 and MoP facilitates to create of S vacancies on the basal plane of MoS2 and expose coordination-unsaturated Mo atoms, which can introduce new active sites on MoS2-MoP/NC to enhance alkaline HER catalytic performance. Similar to the hydrothermal method, the solvothermal method refers to a chemical reaction in a closed system, such as an autoclave, in which organic matter or non-aqueous solvent is the solvent at a certain temperature and the autogenous pressure of the solution [102]. Luo et al. [59] successfully synthesized a novel Mo-doped Ni3S2/Ni x P y heterogeneous hollow nanorod structure (Mo-Ni3S2/Ni x P y /NF) on NF through a simple solvothermal method. First, the Mo-Ni3S2 flower-like nanosheet clusters can effectively control the electronic structure of the catalyst and accurately activate the Ni sites in the Ni3S2 nanostructure. With the introduction of the Mo element, the original Ni3S2 nanosheets formed Mo-Ni3S2 flower-like nanosheet clusters during the solvothermal process. Then, the precursor Mo-Ni3S2 clusters were further phosphatized to produce layered branched Mo-Ni3S2/Ni x P y /NF hollow nanorods with abundant heterogeneous interfaces. Unsurprisingly, the prepared Mo-Ni3S2/Ni x P y /NF electrode exhibits ultra-low overpotential to HER/OER in 1 mol L−1 KOH electrolyte. In addition, when coupled in an alkaline electrolyzer, only an ultra-low cell voltage is required to drive the overall water splitting. Yuan et al. [103] reported a one-step solvothermal approach to directly grow Fe-doped Ni3S2 nanosheet array catalytic material on FeNi alloy foils. First, FeNi alloy foil was selected as the substrate and mixed with sodium sulfide, ethanol in a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave for 12 h at 200 °C. The resulting in-situ grown Fe-Ni3S2/FeNi nanoarrays skillfully avoid the addition of adhesives such as nafion. Fe-Ni3S2 was uniformly fixed to the FeNi alloy during the solvothermal process, resulting in the exposure of a large number of active sites to further enhance the OER performance. For the first time, Yao et al. [104] used an innovative hydrothermal-electrodeposition technique to grow NiCoFeZn alloy coatings directly on nanofibers for the first time ((Fig. 2(e))). With an overpotential of 195 mV, the resulting NiCoFe-PS nanorods can deliver 10 mA cm−2 for OER. NiCoFe/NF nanorods react with P and S to create NiCoFe-PS/NF when selective dealloying is achieved by regulating the potential. During the breakdown of NaH2PO2, P is produced. The catalyst crystallized after a 1-hour sulfidation and phosphating procedure. 3.2 Electrochemical deposition With regard to coating technology, electrochemical deposition describes the transmission of current through positive and negative ions in electrolyte solution while being affected by an external electric field, as well as the redox reaction of gaining and losing electrons on the electrode [64]. Nanostructured templates such as metal foam, metal foil and FTO glass are commonly acted as cathode substrates [106]. A large number of TMSs such as MoS2/Ni3S2/NF [107], Ni-FeS2 [108], Co-S [109], NiFeMoS [110], Ni-Fe-Co-S [111], (Ni-Fe)S x /NiFe(OH) y [112], NiS-CoS [113], have been prepared through electrochemical deposition. The structure and morphology of catalytic materials are largely affected in the electrochemical deposition process by the reaction temperature, electric potential, deposition time, substrate and pH of the electrolyte. Xu et al. [114] successfully obtained ultrathin (about 1.8 nm) heterogeneous nanosheets (Ni(OH)2/Ni3S2) via a simple one-step electrochemical deposition technique. The heterogeneous interface constructed during the electrochemical deposition process not only effectively reduces the surface work function but also promotes the adsorption of OH− to intermediate substances. With improved electrolyte infiltration and bubble escape, the loosening and connecting nanoforest-like design also makes it easier for active areas to be fully exposed. As a result, the obtained Ni(OH)2/Ni3S2 electrocatalyst exhibited prominent catalytic activity for HER (50 mV@10 mA cm−2) and OER (210 mV@10 mA cm−2). More remarkably, when applied as the dual-function electrocatalyst, requires only 1.64 V cell voltage to deliver 100 mA cm−2 for overall water splitting in alkaline. Liu et al. [105] reported the preparation of S-NiFe2O4/NF nanoarrays on NF by in-situ thiourea-assisted electrodeposition and low-temperature calcination. Thanks to the reasonably designed in-situ electrodeposition approach, the obtained S-NiFe2O4/NF had the attractive conductivity, thus exhibited fascinating performance in both HER and OER, and it also displayed excellent stability during the overall water splitting. Yao et al. [104] developed efficient, stable and low-cost bifunctional NiCoFe-PS nanorods on NF by a novel hydrothermoelectric deposition method. Compared with traditional electrodeposition, hydrothermal deposition improves the crystallinity of the catalyst, resulting in a stronger bonding between the catalyst and the conductive substrate. In addition, the surface roughness and specific surface area of the catalyst were increased significantly, which exposed more active sites to further enhance the catalytic activity. 3.3 Liquid phase exfoliation The Liquid-phase exfoliation (LPE) method refers to the homogeneous liquid phase or melts through a certain mechanism to separate into two different components of the immiscible liquid phase method. Among them, ultrasonic is a common auxiliary means in the liquid phase stripping method. LPE has been widely applied in the fields of electrochemical energy storage and catalysis of layered structures. A typical LPE process focuses on the connection between each step, as shown in Fig. 3 , which mainly includes immersion, insertion, exfoliation, and stabilization. A large number of two-dimensional nanostructures can be prepared by mixing TMSs with appropriate solvents and polymers [115]. For example, Huang et al. [116] successfully obtained MoS2 nanosheets using the liquid phase exfoliation method assisted by formamide solvothermal treatment ((Fig. 4(a) )). The exfoliation efficiency in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) was enhanced by the synergetic effect of easier intercalation of polar solvent and higher repulsive force of the treated bulk MoS2 [116]. Zhou et al. [117] successfully exfoliated MoS2 with an extremely low concentration of block copolymer alcohol system. At the same time, the output of nanosheets is increased by about 5% (per hour) through the ordinary ultrasonic method, and as an electrocatalyst to efficiently produce hydrogen. Li et al. [118] prepared and reported the massive production of large-sized and monolayered NiPS3 flakes with high quality by electrochemical cathodic exfoliation of bulk NiPS3 crystals ((Fig. 4(b))). The exfoliated NiPS3 flakes have unprecedented sizes (area ≈ 150 µm2) with an atomic-level thickness (monolayer ratio: ≈ 70%) and have an extremely low degree of oxidation and defects with the intrinsic structure preserved. Importantly, NiPS3 flakes exfoliated by cationic intercalation are not contaminated by oxygen groups. Interestingly, the S atoms and P atoms on the substrate surface of LSTL NiPS3 are the real active sites for HER and OER, respectively [118]. According to (Fig. 4(c)), Xu et al. [119] created a composite of MoS2 and graphene (MG) by simultaneously exfoliating both materials using a liquid-phase salt-assisted technique. The developed catalytic material displays improved stability in HER and an extremely low Tafel slope. 3.4 Chemical vapor deposition Chemical gases or vapors react on the surface of a substrate using a process known as chemical vapor deposition (CVD) to create coatings or nanomaterials. The idea behind it is straightforward: two or more gaseous raw materials are added to a reaction chamber, where they combine to create a new material that is then deposited on the wafer's surface. It is now often utilized in the production of materials for electrocatalysis [120]. For example, Zhu et al. [121] created Se:CoS2–x core-shell nanostructures using a straightforward two-step technique that included chemical vapor deposition and hydrothermal processing ((Fig. 5(c) )). The developed material exhibits remarkable electrochemical performance as a result of the synergistic interaction between CoS2 and CoSe1–x as well as the abundance of active sites in the electrode structure. Additionally, in order to further improve the electrochemical performance of CoS2. Yao et al. [122] created N-CoS2/NF through hydrothermal electrodeposition ((Fig. 5(d))), which had exceptional HER activity and durability and an overpotential of 28 mV to produce a current density of 10 mA cm−2, outperforming nearly all TMS-based electrocatalysts documented in the literature. Subsequently, Huang et al. [123] focused on creating catalytic materials with high current densities and created Fe7S8/NGF loaded on N-doped graphene foam using the hydrothermal technique and chemical vapor deposition ((Fig. 5(a))). At 1 mol L−1 KOH, the Fe7S8/NGF catalyst demonstrated good overall water splitting performance, using just 2.21 V of the additional applied voltage to produce a current density of 100 mA cm−2 and maintaining stability for a period of 12 h. A high-performance bifunctional electrocatalyst was created by Chen et al. [124] by combining the unsaturated S vacancy and the impact of C and N doping in MoS2 nanosheets ((Fig. 5(b))). It is suggested to use a novel technique to produce C and N doped MoS2 at high temperatures. Without experiencing any activity loss, this bifunctional catalyst can be run steadily for 30 h at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in 1 mol L−1 KOH. The continuous growth of vertical graphene nanosheets (VGSs), layered FeCoNi hydroxides (FeCoNi(OH) x ), and MoS2 nanosheets on carbon fiber (CF/VGSs/MoS2/FeCoNi(OH) x ) was recently demonstrated by Ji et al. [125] ((Fig. 5(e))). The CF/VMFO preparation procedure involves the CVD methods for growing VGSs on CF and for growing MoS2 nanosheets on VGSs. With overpotentials of 225 and 241 mV reaching 500 and 1000 mA cm−2, the catalyst performs well in OER at large current densities. 3.5 Ball milling The high energy ball grinding process involves using the ball mill's rotation or vibration to cause a hard ball of raw materials to make a powerful impact before being ground and mixed into metal or alloy powder [126–129]. On conductive graphene sheets, Lonkar et al. [130] proposed an eco-friendly in-situ synthesis technique for uniformly spreading MoS2 coated NiS2 nanohybrids ((Fig. 6(a) )). Specifically, nickel oxalate (C2NiO4), ammonium tetrathiomolybdate (NH4MoS4), graphite oxide, and S were constantly homogenized in a ball mill. Stainless steel balls are used in this unique tube-driven CON-trolled homogenizer, which operates at 4000 r min−1 for 60 min. Particles with an equal distribution, embedded in metal precursors, and S-layered graphite oxide were produced after ball milling. P-MoS2 catalysts with S vacancies were created by Xue et al. [131] using the solid-phase ion exchange technique ((Fig. 6(b))). Instead of using solvents, this approach to preparation is quicker, safer, and more ecologically friendly than conventional approaches. To create a high-energy non-equilibrium condition and improve atomic diffusion, the MoS2 and P powders were ball-milled with a grinding ball. The S atoms in the MoS2 lattice shift away from their equilibrium positions during the grinding process due to the high energy of the reaction system, resulting in S defects. Then, to create P-MoS2 with S vacancies, some open vacancies are filled with P atoms. The synergistic interaction of P active centers and S vacancies can simultaneously improve conductivity and maximize the adsorption free energy of H/O-containing intermediates, boosting the efficiency of the resultant electrocatalysts, as shown by experimental and theoretical studies. 3.6 Other methods In addition to the above methods, the plasma assisted has been applied to the preparation of transition metal sulfides. Lu and his colleagues [132] have prepared a-MoS x with sulfur vacancy by plasma assisted method. Yang et al. [133] have prepared MoS nanoarrays with stepped edge surface termination structure by microwave hydrothermal approach. Ding and his colleagues [134] successfully synthesized s-vacancies CoS2 using thiourea and cobalt chloride as reactants via a simple one-pot sintering method. Other preparation methods also including solid-phase synthesis [135], electrochemical [136], liquid-phase growth [137], pyrolysis [138,139], wet-chemistry solid-phase synthesis [140], chemical etching [141], annealing [77,142–144], calcination [145], cation exchange [57,146–148]. 4 Advantages of simple-metal sulfide electrocatalysts Simple sulfides mostly refer to metal sulfides made up of a single element, such as Ni3S2, Co3S4, MoS2, etc. TMSs can be classified into two groups, layered and non-layered structure, based on the inherent characteristics of typical single metal sulfides: 4.1 Advantages of layered structure The excellent electrocatalytic activity of TMSs is mostly attributable to the well filled E g bandgap and the adequate H binding energy [149,150]. The crystal structure and element position can be carried out the basic criteria for the division of transition metal sulfides: the first includes layered transition metal sulfides (MS2) and non-layered transition metal sulfides (M x S y ), while the latter includes VB (V), VIB (Mo, W) and other transition metal elements (Fe, Co, Ni, Cu), etc. These differences will inevitably result in abundant electronic and electrochemical properties. Typically, the distinctive layered structure created by S-M-S stacking, which is the primary structural characteristic of layered-transition metal sulfide (M = V, Mo, W), plays a significant role in enhancing the efficiency of electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution. Van der Waals forces between the interlayers of MS2 structures can be easily stripped away to form two-dimensional nanosheets [151] S-M-S can be separated into three different stacking configurations: 1T (one-layer tetragonal), 2H (two-layer hexagonal), and 3R (3-layer triangular lattice). More metal active sites will be exposed when multilayer transition metal sulfide is reduced to a single layer, leading to impressive HER performance [152]. 1T phase and 2H phase make up the crystal structure of VS2. Because of its catalytic activity at the base and edge, the metallic 1T-VS2 has garnered the most interest from researchers of these materials [153]. Xie's research group successfully stripped VS2 blocks via ammonia-assisted strategy in 2011 [154], and the results showed that single-layer S-V-S was realized after massive VS2 was stripped into ultra-thin VS2 (Figs. 7(a)–(c) ). Through density functional theory calculations, Wang et al. [155] found that the adsorption free energy (ΔG H*) of H atom on the VS2 monolayer is 0.26 eV, which is much smaller than that on the basal surface of the double-layer VS2 (ΔG H* = 1.89–1.92 eV). Besides, the effect of H coverage on the HER performance of VS2 has also been verified, that is, the catalytic performance of low H coverage is better than that of high coverage. Xia et al. [156] changed the electronic structure of the catalyst and reduced the hydrogen adsorption free energy by constructing pore defects, resulting in the improvement of the optimized VS2 MLW free energy and internal catalytic activity. Moreover, in the field of synthetic methods, Liang et al. [157] developed a simple hydrothermal way for the first time to grow vertical VS2 nanoplates on a high-density carbon paper. The direct connection between VS2 and carbon paper is conducive to charge carrying and transfer. The special structure is also beneficial to the timely escape of hydrogen bubbles on the catalyst surface. It has been widely debated that molybdenum (MoS2) with a two-dimensional layered structure would make an enhanced hydrogen evolution catalyst [158]. Compared to 1T, the 2H phase is more stable. However, during the development of the hydrogen, the active sites in the 2H phase exhibit semiconductor capabilities, and as a result, the base surface is electrochemically inert. When compared to the 2H phase, the 1T phase performed remarkably well due to an increase in charge conductivity, an increase in hydrophilicity, and the presence of electrochemically active bases. Lukowski et al. [159] successfully transformed MoS2 from 2H to 1T via Li intercalation method for the first time. The microphology before and after MoS2 transformation is shown in Figs. 7(d,f), and it can be seen that the size of 1T phase MoS2 is reduced and thinner, showing remarkable metallic properties, excellent electrochemical activity, and outstanding hydrogen evolution kinetics. At present, one of the most popular methods to synthesize 1T-MoS2 is the alkali metal stripping way. However, the aqueous phase synthesis of 1T-MoS2 is still hindered owing to alkali ion intercalation, spontaneous combustion, expensive organic solvents, low enrichment, and difficult reproducibility. Venkateshwaran et al. [160] obtained more than 90% of 1T phase selection in MoS2 by introducing Santa Barbara amorphous-15 (SBA-15) as a template. This is the first time to observe the phase selection behavior of SBA-15 for the whole layered material, which solves the problems of low reproducibility, storage instability, and limited mass production in aqueous phase synthesis of 1T-MoS2. In addition, this 1T-MoS2 can drive a current density of 10 mA cm−2 with an overpotential of 252 mV, and the Tafel slope value is 45 mV dec−1, resulting in an excellent electrochemical activity. Yang et al. [161] processed 2H-MoS2 by a simple one-pot annealing method in a mixed gas of Ar and phosphorus vapor. As shown in (Fig. 7(e)), P can not only occupy the gap of MoS2, resulting in the expansion of MoS2 but also can be embedded into the lattice phase of MoS2, inducing the partial transformation of MoS2 from 2H phase to 1T phase. The planar 1T-2H phase MoS2 heterostructure displays greatly improved hydrogen evolution reaction electrocatalytic performance in alkaline electrolyte, which is mainly ascribed to its significantly modified conductivity, highly exposed active sites, and hydrophilicity. Unfortunately, the catalytic mechanism has not yet been clarified. Jiang et al. [162] explored HER activity on the base plane of 1T-MoS2 prototype material through periodic density functional theory DFT calculation. Compared with the inert substrate of the 2H phase, the superior performance of the 1T phase substrate is mainly owing to its affinity for binding H at the S site on the surface. Taking the binding free energy of H (ΔG H*) as a descriptor, the reaction energy and barrier of three basic steps in HER process are discussed. Volmer reactions occur easily, and the subsequent Heyrovsky reaction is more favorable in kinetics than Tafel reaction. The results show that HER can occur based on 1T-MoS2 via Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanical under the low overpotential. As a typical two-dimensional layered material with superior HER performance, WS2 shares many structural and physical characteristics with MoS2. High concentration metal edges are present in the XS2 (X = Mo, W) nanoparticles with 2H [163]. Increasing the number of active sites and catalytic activity is the development direction for WS2. M. Chhowalla et al. [164] synthesized the single-layered WS2 nanosheets as efficient HER electrocatalysts through the chemical exfoliated method, the results of this report indicate that the enhancement performance is related to the high concentration of 1T metal phase. Kumar et al. [165] captured the exciton effect originated near the edge of the conduction band for layered 2H WS2 through theoretical calculation and proved that 1T-WS2 will expose more abundant active sites than 2H. However, the excellent stability of 2H-WS2 leads to the limited and complex method of synthesizing 1T-WS2. Kim [166] prepared uniform wafer-level 1T-WS2 films through plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition, which can be synthesized directly on the rigid dielectric and flexible polymer substrates. Compared with the previously reported chemical vapor deposition and hydrothermal methods, 1T-WS2 obtained by this preparation method has the same excellent catalytic activity and stability. In addition, it will not be converted into stable 2H-WS2, even if it continues to work for 700 h. Yang et al. [167] reported a new high-temperature liquid phase synthesis of ultrathin WS2 nanosheets. The resulting product has the characteristics of single-layer thickness, nanometer size, and rich edges. These favorable structures promote the excellent performance of WS2 nanosheets in acidic environments: an ultra-low overpotential of 100 mV and a Tafel slope of 48 mV dec−1. Different from the ion stripping method, Yu et al. [168] reported a fast, simple and insensitive method to synthesize WS2 NDs from bulk WS2 “top to bottom”. [169] explored a simple method for synthesizing ultrathin WS2 nanosheets at low temperatures. They are loosely stacked between highly exposed layers, providing a large number of active sites for electrochemical applications. 4.2 Advantages of non-layered structure Fe, Co, Ni, Cu based sulfides [170–174] have the advantage of controllable chemical properties, diverse structure morphology, and enhanced chemical performance among the non-layered transition metal sulfides, which is attributed to their partially filled electronic orbitals and variable valence states. The Fe element has a 3d 64s 2 electron configuration. Many phase structures, including FeS, FeS2, FeS3, and Fe3S4, are present in the iron-based sulfide FeS x , which has numerous valence states. FeS2 has been extensively explored as a type of energy storage and conversion catalytic material and is credited with the benefits of natural pyrite FeS2, which has a superior catalytic efficiency and a significant crustal abundance. However, the low conductivity (10−4 S/cm) of the nano-pyrite film results in issues such low conductivity, sluggish electron transfer speed, and poor intrinsic activity of FeS2, which significantly reduces the catalytic activity of FeS2 materials [175,176]. To solve the above problems, Xiong et al. [177] demonstrated a simple electropolymerization and hydrothermal method to synthesize FeS2/polyaniline/exfoliated graphene (FeS2/PANI/ EG) with crystalline and amorphous interfaces to enhance electrocatalytic activity. The polyaniline layer with randomly distributed porous structure is composed of nanowires with a diameter of about 100 nm. S element is doped into polyaniline through the formed C–S bond. The diameter of FeS2 is distributed between 5–15 nm to ensure the successful construction of crystalline and amorphous interfaces. The obtained FeS2-RGO three-dimensional nanostructure helps to maintain the mechanical stability and electron transfer rate of FeS2 nanoparticles in RGO nanosheets. In acidic conditions, the electrocatalytic performance test exhibits remarkably improved activity for HER, achieving 10 mA cm−2 current against a reversible hydrogen electrode with remarkable long-term stability in an acidic environment at an overpotential as low as 139 mV. In addition, Liu et al. [180] first predicted the H* adsorption energy of FeS2 supported transition metal single atoms (M@FeS2) as HER and OER electrocatalysts by density functional theory (DFT). The results showed that the M@FeS2 catalyst had excellent thermal stability and excellent electrochemical reaction conductivity. Among them, the transition metal atoms were identified as the active sites of HER and OER. Cr@FeS2 activity is even much higher than that of the most effective Pt catalyst at present, with an ultra-low (0.049 V) ΔG H* value and energy barrier of 0.22 eV for HER. The Co element has the electronic configuration 3d 74s 2. Electrical conductivity has led to the identification of cobalt pyrite (CoS2) as a powerful electrocatalyst for oxygen reduction. CoS2 has clear advantages over layered transition metal disulfide electrocatalysts since it is a stable intrinsic metal mineral. For example, MoS2 and WS2 display high HER activity on the premise that they are transformed from a thermodynamically favorable semiconductor phase to a metastable metal polymorph. Shanmugam and co-workers [182] discovered unprecedentedly striking oxygen electrode activity of CoS2(400)/N, S-GO, which showed comparable activity with precious catalysts. [183] reported a method for preparing cubic Co9S8 hollow spheres with special structure and porosity in a binary solution of ethylene glycol-dimethylformamide. Xu et al. [184] synthesized self-assembled three-dimensional (3D) CoS2 microspheres with ultra-thin flower shapes. CoS2 microspheres showed inherent high OER activity under alkaline conditions. [172] demonstrated the construction of CoS2 nanosheets of assembled three-dimensional graded microcapsules through a simple solvothermal process and subsequent vulcanization, in which the porous components were crosslinked by nanoparticles. Based on the above research, research experts attempt to combine theoretical calculations to thoroughly and comprehensively explore the real active substances in the entire reaction process. Hou et al. [185] confirmed that the unique three-dimensional hierarchical structure and interface reconstruction formed by Ni–S bonding of Ni3Se2 and Co9S8 will significantly improve the electrochemical activity of the obtained materials through experimental research and theoretical calculation. This causes the redistribution of charge, which reduces desorption energy barrier of hydrogen in the process of water splitting. Zhang et al. [134] developed an N-doped CoS2 electrocatalytic material implantation the synergistic effect of N drops and S vacancies. The catalyst showed high hydrogen evolution reaction activity (10 mA cm−2@370 mV) and amazing stability. First-principles calculations and experimental results indicate that N-doping can enhance the activity of adjacent cobalt sites, and the hydrogen adsorption free energy (ΔG H*) is reduced from 0.41 to 0.31 eV. In the presence of sulfur vacancies, the N dopant can be a new active site with a ΔG H* value of 0.11 eV to effectively accelerate the slow HER kinetics. Subsequently, Li et al. [186] reported an effective surface modification technique for preparing O and N-doped Co9S8 (O-, N-Co9S8) catalysts, which showed excellent activity, especially for OER. In addition, they also found that O-, N-Co9S8 was completely converted into Co3O4 after OER, indicating that the oxide is the actual active phase. It is proposed and proved that the oxides in-situ generated during the OER process are more active than the directly calcined oxides. Fan et al. On this basis, the combination of CoS x and 3D N-doped graphene foam makes it completely converted into CoOOH during the OER process, which extremely improves the activity of the electrocatalyst. Single metal sulfides reveal obvious potential in OER and HER as the best candidates to replace precious metals. Tables 1–3 lists some reported advances of these electrocatalysts. 5 Modification of metal sulfide Although the single-metal sulfide catalyst has made impressive strides in the field of electrocatalytic water splitting, it is still unable to attain commercial applications. To enhance catalytic performance and stability, adjustments should be performed continuously. The following guidelines ought to be used as a guide during the particular alteration process: (1) The potential catalytic activity of materials is directly related to their intrinsic catalytic activity; (2) The catalytic activity of the catalyst can be improved by increasing the number and density of active sites exposed on its surface; (3) The material’s conductivity is improved to enable electron transfer throughout the catalytic process and to lower the voltage of the extra electrode; (4) The adsorption/desorption capacity of reaction intermediates is related to the reaction energy barrier of the catalyst; (5) In order to enable the penetration of the electrolyte and the release of bubbles, the material’s capacity for charge transfer should be improved. The optimization of their intrinsic activity is then explained by a number of modification measures of single metal sulfide [150,270]. 5.1 Combination The activity of single-metal sulfide can be increased through compounding with other substances. Typically, certain non-metal or metal complexes with catalytic activity will be chosen. The combination of these can considerably increase the materials’ catalytic performance [271,272]. Additionally, the active interface’s catalytic sites can be increased and the kinetics of interfacial charge transfer can be improved using heterostructures. Researchers have invested a considerable deal of time and energy into theory and experimentation to fully understand the internal elements that contribute to the performance improvement of composite electrocatalytic materials [273]. In order to lower the reaction energy barrier and increase catalytic activity, compound recombination can control the interaction between electronic structures and impact the binding energy of reaction intermediates. This section primarily focuses on the changes in electronic structure brought on by composites. 5.1.1 Mixed-metal-sulfide composites Mixtures of bimetallic sulfides illustrate superior catalytic performance than their monometallic counterparts. When two or more metal substances are combined, more active sites can be exposed, thereby improving the electrochemical reaction kinetics [274,275]. Importantly, bimetallic sulfides tend to form heterogeneous interfaces, which can facilitate the dissociation of H2O molecules and enhance electrocatalytic performance [276,277]. Just as Box et al. [251] chose low-cost melamine sponge with low cost and continuous three-dimensional network macrostructure as the raw material for the preparation of nerve growth factor, MoS2/Ni2S3 bimetallic sulfide was prepared by the template-assisted method. The results demonstrated that the obtained MoS2-Ni2S3 nerve growth factor can fully combine the advantages of a three-dimensional graphene network and bimetallic sulfide, and receive more active sites, lower overpotential than the corresponding counterpart. This synergistic effect clearly shows that there is a strong interaction between the components, resulting in excellent performance for HER and OER. This dual-functional catalyst also exhibits excellent overall water splitting ability, with a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at 1.64 V battery voltage. The electrocatalytic activity of WS2, a typical two-dimensional material, can also be considerably increased by manipulating its structure with more exposed active sites due to the structural similarities and electrons of MoS2. In addition, WS2 has low conductivity, which limits charge transfer and electrocatalytic performance. On the other hand, cobalt sulfide (CoS x ) is essentially a conductive metal, in contrast to other semiconducting pyrites, making it a promising electrocatalyst as a carrier for other electrocatalyst materials. As expected, when Co9S8/WS2 is applied as two electrodes in the alkaline hydro hydrolysis tank and the battery voltage is 1.65 V, the current density of 10 mA cm−2 can be achieved. Chen et al. [278] designed a complex metal chalcogenide-based composite material. The synthesis steps of Co9S8/Zn0.8Co0.2S@C are shown in (Fig. 8(a) ). The excellent thermal adsorption performance of the catalyst can be attributed to the reasonably adjusted heterogeneous interface and electronic structure, which can achieve strong water absorption and hydrogen atom desorption, promote rapid electron transfer, and enhance H2 release. 5.1.2 Hybridizing with other electroactive materials In addition, another strategy to improve the catalytic performance of single metal sulfides is to form nanocomposites by introducing carbon materials. Using carbon as a carrier, catalysts with large surface area and high catalytic activity can be obtained by dispersing the active components onto carbon materials with definite nanostructures [281–283]. Li et al. [284] successfully synthesized a new nanostructure of Ni3S2 nanowires@nitrogen-doped graphene-like carbon layer on NF substrate (Ni3S2@NGCLs/NF) using nickel foam as skeleton and nickel source, thiourea as sulfur and carbon precursor, and urea as nitrogen precursor by conventional chemical vapor deposition. The novel Ni3S2@NGCLs hetero-structures possessed both highly efficient OER and HER activities in alkaline solution, with overpotentials at 10 mA cm−2 as low as 271 and 132 mV, respectively (Figs. 9(c), (e) ). Furthermore, an alkaline electrolyzer assembled using the as-prepared Ni3S2@NGCLs heterostructures could deliver a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at a low cell voltage of 1.55 V ((Fig. 9(g))). As shown in Figs. 9(i) and (j), DFT calculations show that Ni3S2@NGCLs/NF has the smallest H free energy of adsorption and the lowest OER reaction energy barrier. The as-prepared Ni3S2@NGCLs/NF composite electrocatalyst has several advantages: (1) One-dimensional nanowire electrocatalysts can improve the intrinsic activity of the catalyst and increase the number of catalytically active sites. (2) The carbon shell structure can promote the electron transfer rate since the one-dimensional graphene-like carbon layer can be applied as a continuous nanostructured connector. (3) The independent nanowire array can accelerate the mass diffusion dynamics, and the loose structure of the nanowire is conducive to the transfer of ions and reaction products. (4) Abundant nitrogen-doped structures not only enhance electronic conductivity but also increase the number of intrinsic defects and active sites to facilitate the catalytic process. (5) The graphene-like structure of the multilayer carbon slows the dissolution of metal substances in the electrolyte (controllable formation of the active phase NiOOH), which is beneficial to maintain the characteristics of the coordination interface and improve the catalytic stability of the catalyst. The p-type semiconductor CoS x tends to develop distinct interfaces and turn into an electron acceptor site, causing a negative shift to low energy. Because of the characteristics of the NiFe LDH n-type semiconductor, electrons are transferred from Ni to Co. More positive nickel valence states and negative cobalt valence states will result from this Ni → Co electron transfer pathway. The adsorption state, which is advantageous for the improvement of electrocatalytic activity, will be impacted by the change in valence state via changing the electron density and electronic structure. The optimized NiFe-LDH@CoS x /NF electrocatalyst has high catalytic activity for HER (η 10 = 136 mV) and OER (η 10 = 206 mV). Song et al. [288] successfully developed a simple strategy for the preparation of (Co1–x Ni x )(S1–y P y )2/GO bifunctional electrocatalysts. Among them, the self-assembly of the 2D nanosheets to form the three-dimensional structure (Co1–x Ni x )(OH)2 precursor is achieved through a wet chemical process without any template or surfactant. As shown in (Fig. 9(a)) and (b), the (Co1–x Ni x )(S1–y Py)2 particle's open 3D structure can offer a lot of active sites and ion diffusion pathways. Additionally, the electrocatalytic activity is enhanced by the dual adjustment of Ni and P at the sites of Co and S. (Co1–x Ni x )(S1–y Py)2/GO demonstrated good electrocatalytic HER and OER performance during the examination of electrochemical performance (Figs. 9(c) and (e)) and stability (Figs. 9(d) and (f)). A battery voltage of 1.55 V may drive a dual-electrode system with a current density of 10 mA cm−2 ((Fig. 9(g))). DFT analysis further supported the idea that (Co1–x Ni x )(S1–y P y )2/GO may successfully lower the reaction energy barrier of OER/HER, resulting in superior electrochemical performance. The creation of a heterogeneous interface can offer additional contact area to fully expose active sites and accomplish the high-efficiency electrocatalytic activity in comparison to conventional nanomaterials with restricted active sites. Zhang et al. [291] synthesized two-dimensional NiS/graphene heterostructure composites in one step by pyrolysis vulcanization process with new deep eutectic solvents (DESs) as precursors. The optimized heterostructure catalyst showed a low battery voltage of 1.54 V in an alkaline medium at 10 mA cm−2 current density, even superior to Pt/C and IrO2 on the integrated catalyst. Zeng et al. [253] designed and prepared a novel three-dimensional (3D) network heterogeneous Ni2P/Ni3S2 electrocatalyst in situ on nickel foam, as shown in (Fig. 10(a) ), which was formed by the strong coupling of Ni2P and Ni3S2. The best 3D network hybrid electrode demonstrated exceptional electrocatalytic activity as a result of its huge surface area, highly conductive NF support, unique 3D open design, and strong interfacial coupling effect between Ni2P and Ni3S2. Ni2P/Ni3S2 has a low HER/OER overpotential of 80 and 210 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2, respectively, as illustrated in Figs. 10(b) and (e). The G H* of H adsorption on the Ni2P (001) and Ni3S2 (101) surfaces, respectively, are –0.37 and –0.85 eV, as shown in (Fig. 10(d)). The G H* of the Ni2P/Ni3S2 heterostructure, on the other hand, changes substantially to –0.12 eV, which is relatively close to the ideal ΔG H* of 0 eV for the Catalyst-H* state. When compared to pure Ni2P and Ni3S2, the Ni2P/Ni3S2 heterostructure is in the metallic state with an improved carrier density near the Fermi level, according to the computed density of the states ((Fig. 10(c))). Because of the elevated electron transfer, the larger electron density at the Fermi level increases electrical conductivity and aids in improving electrochemical performance. Because of this, the theoretical and computational results indicate that the Ni2P/Ni3S2 HNAs/NF catalyst is really a highly active electrocatalyst for water splitting. Zhou et al. [292] successfully obtained defect-rich foam-like Co9S8/Ni3S2 nanowire arrays through in-situ vulcanization. The Co9S8/Ni3S2 electrode showed low OER/HER overpotentials of 227 and 128 mV. [259] proposed a one-step method of simultaneously phosphating and vulcanizing nanoparticles at low temperatures to directly grow Ni-S-P heterogeneous nanorod arrays composed of Ni3S2 and Ni2P on NF. This excellent catalytic performance should be attributed to: (1) Nanorods growing directly on NF without polymer binder avoid aggregation or reaccumulation and allow tight adhesion between catalyst and substrate. Theoretical calculations confirmed that the Ni3S2/Ni2P heterostructure is in a metal state with high conductivity, and its superior pH universal HER activity comes from the proper hydrogen adsorption free energy and the coupling between Ni3S2 and Ni2P. Wang et al. [289] reported the in-situ sulfur doping of carbon nanotubes and the simultaneous growth of Co9S8 nanoparticles on carbon nanotubes by a simple and effective solvothermal method. As shown in (Fig. 10(f)), Co9S8 nanoparticles are uniformly distributed on the carbon nanotubes, and HRTEM images ((Fig. 10(g))) clearly show that Co9S8 and CNTs form heterojunction interfaces, providing a large number of active sites that contribute to outstanding electrochemical performance. Finally, subnanometer Cu clusters and amorphous CoS on CF were produced by Liu et al. [293] using a straightforward hydrothermal technique. The release of H2 and OH* would be facilitated and the performance of the electrochemical reaction as a whole would be improved. This is because the transfer of electron density from Co species to Cu clusters might result in more positively charged Co species and negatively charged Cu clusters. Kim et al. [290] introduced ultra-small Co9S8 nanoparticles on the MoS2 base surface to construct a covalent 0D-2D heterostructure to maximize the intrinsic catalytic activity of MoS2. In the heterostructure, the two phases are connected by Co-S-Mo type covalent bonds instead of the ordinary van der Waals heterostructure. The electrons are moved from Co to Mo atoms, enriching the electrons in the Mo location and boosting the proton affinity. Additionally, the inert base surface of MoS2 next to Co9S8 was further activated by a significant number of S defects, which improved the electron doping capabilities. When the curved MoS2 array covers the surface of Mo2C in the core-shell nanostructures of Mo2C and MoS2 created by Tiwari (Figs. 10(h), (i)), the base surface of MoS2 is transformed from being inactive to having high activity in alkaline electrolytes, improving the stability of the core-shell structure. As a result, extremely active ORR and OER are produced. It also offers a useful method for transferring electrons via spin coupling [294]. 5.2 Designing vacancies 5.2.1 Cation vacancies The existence of defects can directly destroy the periodic crystal structure of the material, and adjust the surface electronic structure through localized electron redistribution. Introducing defects in the field of electrocatalysis can effectively adjust the electronic structure of the catalyst, the adsorption energy of intermediates, and the reaction pathway, thus improving the catalyst activity of the material. Liu et al. [295] used nickel vanadium LDH (Ni-V LDH) nanosheets as the precursor, and obtained V-doped pyrite NiS2 nanosheets after sulfidation treatment as a dual-functional electrode material for hydrogen evolution and oxygen evolution reactions ((Fig. 11(a) )). After 10% V doping with NiS2, the typical pyrite NiS2 morphology is still preserved ((Fig. 11(b))). However, as shown in (Fig. 11(c)), the diffraction peak of 10% V-NiS2 is slightly shifted to a larger angle than the diffraction peak of bare NiS2, indicating that the lattice parameters of doped NiS2 decrease, which may be due to the difference in atomic radius between the Ni vacancy and V atom. Notably, the engineering application of V-displacement defects revealed by detailed experimental studies and density functional theory calculations enabled the electronic restructuring of pyrite NiS2 from typical semiconductor properties to metal properties. In addition, detailed X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) measurements further indicate that the electronic structure reconstruction of NiS2 originates from the transfer of electrons from the doped V site to the Ni site (Figs. 11(d), (e)), thereby allowing the Ni site to obtain more electrons. The optimal metal V-doped NiS2 nanosheets showed excellent electrocatalytic performance. At 10 mA cm−2, the overpotentials of OER and HER can be as low as 290 mV ((Fig. 11(f))) and 110 mV ((Fig. 11(g))), respectively, maintaining long-term catalytic stability. In addition, using it as a dual-function electrode material also shows outstanding performance for overall water splitting ((Fig. 11(h))). Li et al. [296] proposed a flexible and scalable two-step synthesis strategy to fabricate Ni-Fe-P-Ni3S2 heterogeneous catalyst (Ni-Fe-P- Ni3S2/NF) on NF. The obtained Ni-Fe-P-Ni3S2 catalyst has abundant lattice defects, highly open morphology, large surface area, a large number of suspended boundaries around the Ni center, as well as a synergistic effect between Ni-Fe-P alloy and Ni3S2. Based on the above characteristics, Ni-Fe-P-Ni3S2 exhibits remarkable catalytic activity and long-term stability for HER, OER, and overall water splitting reactions in an alkaline medium. In order to facilitate the chemical adsorption of OH* on the Ni3S4 surface and the transfer of electrons from OH* to Ni site during the OER process, Wan et al. [191] synthesized a layered porous Ni3S4 material rich in Ni3+. The microporous structure promotes mass transportation and increases the number of active spots. The observed Ni3S4 system structure has an overpotential of 257 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and 300 mV at 50 mA cm−2. The battery voltage is 1.51 V at 10 mA cm−2 with Ni3S4 acting as the anode catalyst and Pt/C acting as the cathode catalyst. 5.2.2 Anion vacancies Besides the cation vacancies, the introduction of anion vacancies can also effectively regulate the electronic performance of the catalyst and improve the intrinsic activity of active sites. The porous structure further improves electrocatalytic performance by increasing the number of active sites, shortening the transfer distance of electrons. However, the preparation of non-layered transition metal-based ultra-thin, porous, and high-efficiency electrocatalytic nanoarrays rich in anion vacancies is still a formidable challenge [297]. Zhang et al. [298] first formed Ni3S2/MnS nanosheets in situ on the NF via a two-step hydrothermal reaction and then generated Ni3S2/MnS-O in the shape of a white fungus by slightly electro-oxidizing Ni3S2/MnS ((Fig. 12(a) )). It has ultra-thin nanosheets, abundant oxygen vacancies (NF/T/Ni3S2/MnS-O) ((Fig. 12(b))). OVs increase the conductivity, promote the adsorption kinetics process of H2O on HER or OH− on OER. Moreover, the hierarchical porous structure and high active surface area ensure sufficient exposure of OVs, enhance the mass transfer rate of HER/OER intermediates, finally show excellent HER (116 mV@10 mA cm−2) ((Fig. 12(d)))/OER (228 mV@10 mA cm−2) ((Fig. 12(f))) performance. In order to create the electrocatalyst S-NiFe2O4, Jin et al. [299] coupled the sulfur and oxygen vacancies (VO) of the inverse spinel NiFe2O4 ((Fig. 12(g))). Because S atoms are doped into NiFe2O4 and linked with VO, the ESR signal of S-NiFe2O4 is less than that of NiFe2O4, as illustrated in (Fig. 12(h)). This distinct and distinctive structure is anticipated to facilitate the generation of S–H* intermediates, accelerate the reaction process, and lower the energy barrier of site-to-site electron transfer, resulting in HER having outstanding catalytic activity in alkaline solutions (80 mV@10 mAcm−2) ((Fig. 12(i))). The DFT calculation approach was used to look at the HER characteristics of S-NiFe2O4. The original NiFe2O4 exhibits an electron-rich structure near the surface O site and the octahedral Fe site based on the bonding and anti-bonding orbital distribution near the Fermi level. The local lattice distortion also causes an alteration in the electron distribution, which activates the electroactivity of the metal sites on the surface. Additionally, PDOSs reveals the electronic composition of several components in S-NiFe2O4 while highlighting the strong electroactivity and minor barrier between the t2g and eg of the Fe-3d orbitals. The steady H adsorption during the alkaline HER process is made easier by the proximity of the Ni sites to E F. As the electron providers for the Fe-sites that activate the H2O molecules, the s, p orbitals of O and S, which have a wide range from E V –8.0 eV to E V + 4.0 eV (E V = 0 eV), play a key role ((Fig. 12(j))). The efficient change in H adsorption structure brought on by S injection in experiments is guaranteed by the stable electroactivity of Ni sites ((Fig. 12(k))). The first H2O adsorption demonstrated a 0.14 eV energy decrease trend, which served as the basis for the successful performance of HER. The subsequent step of determining the H2O dissociation rate reveals a low energy barrier of 0.12 eV. Then, the energy barrier for the rate-determining phase of H2O dissociation is less at 0.12 eV, with an energy release of 0.30 eV ((Fig. 12(i))). Che et al. [300] proposed an amorphous Ni3S2 nanocluster modified by trimetallic (Fe-Ni) Co x -OH nano-film and supported S vacancies on NF through a fast two-step electrodeposition approach. By effectively breaking the long process of Ni3S2 to form the S-vacancy amorphous phase and combining with the strong electron interaction between (Fe-Ni) Co x -OH and Ni3S2, Ni3S2 has excellent water adsorption capacity, ΔG H* and fast charge transfer process. (Fe-Ni)Co x -OH/Ni3S2 nano-hybrid materials have overpotentials of 91 and 145 mV at 100 mA cm−2 and 400 mA cm−2, respectively, and 200 mA cm−2 in 1 mol L−1 KOH. The endurance time is 100 h, which even exceeds Pt/C. Zhang et al. [301] proposed a plasma-induced dry exfoliation method to synthesis non-layered Co3S4 ultra-thin porous nanosheets with rich sulfur vacancies (Co3S4 PNSvac) ((Fig. 13(a) )).
