Moreover, the plasma-assisted conversion method can also be extended to prepare CoSe2 and NiSe2 ultra-thin porous nanosheets with selenium vacancies. Li et al. [134] exploited the synergistic effect of N dopants and S vacancies to develop N-doped cobalt pyrite (CoS2) electrocatalytic materials. The calculation results show that N doping can increase the activity of adjacent Co sites, and the hydrogen adsorption free energy (ΔG H*) is reduced from 0.41 to 0.31 eV. Importantly, the S vacancies in N-doped CoS2 can further increase the activity of the Co site, and its ΔG H* value is small, 0.18 eV. In the presence of S vacancies, N can be used as a new active site with a ΔG H* value of 0.11 eV, which effectively accelerates the slow HER dynamics (Figs. 13(c), (d)). Zhang et al. [302] reported a simple method to generate a large concentration of S vacancies in the inert base plane of MoS2 supported by semi-metal CoMoP2. When the application potential is very small, the S atom can be removed as H2S due to the optimization of the free energy of formation. The resulting vacancy can be acted as a new catalytic center for HER, and the presence of the vacancy facilitates electron injection from the electrode to the active site by reducing the contact resistance. The results showed that the catalytic current of the vacancy-rich MoS2 as a hydrogen evolution catalyst increased by 221%. A small overpotential of 75 mV requires a current density of 10 mA cm−2, which is considered to be one of the best values achieved by MoS2. Li et al. [58] reported that the basal plane of monolayer 2H-MoS2 was activated and optimized for the first time by introducing sulfur (S) vacancy and strain ((Fig. 13(g))). S-vacancies are introduced into the interstitial state, allowing favorable hydrogen adsorption. As shown in Figs. 13 (i), (k)), further confirmation of the formation of S vacancies. The increase of the number of S-vacancies enhances hydrogen adsorption, resulting in the simultaneous change of hydrogen adsorption free energy and active site density ((Fig. 13(h))). Squeezing the S vacancy makes the interstitial state closer to the Fermi level, thereby obtaining the optimal ΔG H*. Experiments demonstrate that the optimized MoS2 monolayer with S vacancies has unprecedented high intrinsic HER activity. 5.3 Doping 5.3.1 Cation doping Metal doping is an important method to adjust the electronic structure of the active center of the electrocuted, change the electron density distribution, promote the adsorption and activation of water, and optimize the adsorption and desorption of H to improve the intrinsic electrocatalytic activity. Our group prepared various cation-doped Ni3S2/Co3S4 nanoarrays by a simple alcohol-thermal-sulfurization method ((Fig. 14(a) )) to successfully construct high-valence metal cations [303]. The obtained heterojunction Ni3S2/Co3S4 was confirmed by SEM and TEM (Figs. 14(d), (e)). The doping of cations Mo, Zn, Cu, Fe was confirmed by XRD ((Fig. 14(b))). Among them, as shown in (Fig. 14(c)), the shift of the Co 2p binding energy to a lower position compared to the pristine Ni3S2/Co3S4 confirms that more Co3+ is generated due to the doping effect. As shown in (Fig. 14(i)), it is found that partial electrons prefer to be transferred from Ni2+ to Co2+ via the S2– bridging during the catalytic reaction. At the same time, Cu atom tends to absorb some electrons from Co2+ owing to its high electronegativity. In addition, the Barder charge can also clearly show that Co and Ni are in the electron-loss state during the entire electrochemical reaction process ((Fig. 14(h))), thus modifying their electronic structure to form Ni/CoOOH with high-valence state. Finally, the OER process and the intermediate energy barrier of the HER reaction process were calculated respectively, the Cu-doping promotes intrinsic catalytic activity through modulating the d-band center of Co and reducing the adsorption energy of H and O-containing intermediates (H*, OH*, OOH*) on the surface of the catalyst (Figs. 14(j), (k)). Among them, Cu-Ni3S2/Co3S4 exhibits the highest HER and OER performance, which has a low overpotential of 79 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and 250 mV at 100 mA cm−2 (Figs. 14(f), (g)) [303]. Not only that, Xing et al. [304] demonstrated an effective strategy to construct Pt/Ni3S2/NF by electrodepositing Pt nanoparticles on hydrothermally synthesized Ni3S2/NF. The Pt/Ni3S2/NF heterostructure array that was created has an exceedingly low overpotential of 10 mV at 10 mA cm−2, which is lower than that of Pt/C that is available for sale. The electrode also demonstrates improved stability and catalytic efficacy in neutral media. The interface built in the Pt/Ni3S2/NF heterostructure array is blamed for the increased HER activity, and its synergistic effect is conducive to water dissociation and subsequent hydrogen release. DFT calculations further reveal that the designed Pt/Ni3S2 heterostructure array interface can be synergistically optimized for OH adsorption and H desorption, promoting the Volmer and Heyrovsky steps of HER, thereby exhibiting excellent electrochemical performance. Feng et al. [305] reported a high-efficiency electrocatalyst of Ni3S2 nanotubes (NTs) modified by Cu nanodots (NDs) supported on carbon fibers (CFs) (Cu NDs/Ni3S2 NTs-CFs). It is conducive to the mass transfer and diffusion in the HER process. The easy realization of Hads on the surface of Ni3S2 is mainly attributed to the formation of S–Hads bonds. The electronic interaction between Cu and Ni3S2 makes Cu positively charged, and Ni3S2 negatively charged. Among them, positively charged Cu can effectively adsorb and activate water molecules, which is conducive to H–O decomposition, and negatively charged Ni3S2 can weaken the S–Hads bond, to optimize the adsorption and desorption of H. The above electronic interaction can well optimize the adsorption and desorption of H on the surface of the metal sulfide-based electrocatalyst, effectively promote the Volmer and Heyrovsky steps of HER, and achieve high-efficiency HER in alkaline solution. The Cu NDs/Ni3S2 NTs-CFs catalyst exhibits obviously enhanced OER performance and long-term stability. Tong et al. [306] prepared a Co-doped Ni3S2 nanocone (Co12@Ni3S2/NF) material by vulcanizing CoO nano-films on porous NF using the atomic layer deposition (ALD) method. The electrocatalyst has the characteristics of large specific surface areas, abundant active sites, rapid electron transfer, and high electrochemical activity. First-principles calculation reveals that Co dopant in the Ni3S2 system not only produces the desirable ΔG H* and favorable HER kinetics but also lowers the OER energy barrier (Figs. 15(a)–(d) ). 3D Co12@Ni3S2/NF has extraordinary performance in decomposing water mainly due to the porous structure, low resistance, high effective charge, and abundant lattice distortion. A more important factor to improve HER activity may be the accelerated Volmer dissolution step on the catalyst after doping. On this basis, Zhang et al. [63] prepared a free-standing electrocuted in the form of an array of vertically-oriented Fe-Ni3S2 nanosheets grown on three-dimensional nickel foam((Fig. 15(e))). Based on system experiments and calculations, it is proved that Fe doping increases the electrochemical surface area of Ni3S2 and optimizes the adsorption of H on Ni3S2. In addition, the formation of Ni-Fe(O)OOH was observed in the near-surface part of Fe-Ni3S2/NF during the OER catalytic process ((Fig. 15(f))), and the introduction of the Fe element also significantly enhanced the OER activity of Ni3S2 ((Fig. 15(g))). Based on this, Guo et al. [307] improved the electronic properties of the hybrid mesoporous MoS2/CoMo2S4 material through the Fe-doped spherical mesoporous MoS2/CoMo2S4 heterostructure, so that it has excellent electrochemical activity in HER and OER. Specifically, the mesoporous metal MoS2 hybrid material is prepared by the diblock copolymer polystyrene-block-poly (acrylic acid) micelle soft template method. The formation of mesoporous MoS2/CoMo2S4 heterostructures is based on the complex co-assembly of dithiooxamide and metal precursors, followed by annealing in the N2 atmosphere to generate mesoporous materials. The decomposed polymer leaves mesopores in the entire spherical MoS2/CoMo2S4 mixed particles and generates many electrochemically active sites in the pore network, which makes charge transfer and gas diffusion faster, thereby enhancing the electrocatalytic performance of MoS2/CoMo2S4. Wang et al. [308] synthesized a Co9S8 advanced OER catalyst (Mo-Co9S8@C) modified based on monoatomic Mo (0.99% by weight) (Figs. 16(a)–(d) ). The acidic environment OER is realized through the synergistic effect of the ultra-aerosol structure of the new Mo-Co9S8@C catalyst and the strong metal support in the Co9S8 array. As an efficient and non-precious metal catalyst, it can perform HER/OER reaction under different pH conditions. The preparation method involves direct solvothermal route synthesis for rapid amplification. Partial sulfur oxides serve as anchor sites for Mo single atoms. The catalytic interface has excellent H2O adsorption, O free radical generation, and super-aerosol structure, which is conducive to the release of product bubbles. The multifunctional assembled Mo-Co9S8@C catalyst has the synergistic effect of highly active Co3+ (derived from the charge transfer process) and monoatomic Mo (more inclined to adsorb H2O energy). The electrocatalyst produced by this effect is superior to each individual sample. The Mo-Co9S8@C nanosheet array electrode shows excellent response performance to both HER and OER. Under acidic, alkaline, and neutral media, the overpotential of HER at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 is 98, 113, and 140 mV, respectively. In addition, in acidic, alkaline, and neutral media, it achieves low onset potentials of 200, 90, and 290 mV for OER, which is superior to most of the previously reported noble metal and noble metal-free electrocatalysts (Figs. 16(e)–(h)). The DFT calculation results further show that the excellent electrocatalytic performance is not only owing to the formation of abundant active sites on the surface/interface and the superhydrophobic structure. The unusual coordinated charge transfer coupling effect between Co9S8 and monoatomic Mo species promotes the adsorption of H2O, which is then converted into O radicals on the Co site through proton transfer, and Co3+, which is tuned to a higher electron cloud density by Mo single atom. In addition, contact with the current collector and efficient electron transport, as well as the strong interaction between the atomic metal and the carrier are also conducive to stability and electrocatalytic activity. Li et al. [231] synthesized Co-doped Cu7S4 nanosheets and explored its performance as a high-efficiency OER electrocatalyst by optimizing the electronic structure of the active center. The excellent electrocatalytic performance of the Co-doped Cu7S4 electrode is mainly attributed to the following aspects: (1) Co doping can modulate the electrons in the electrocatalytic active center, enhance electron transfer, and reduce the energy barriers of intermediates and products, thereby increasing intrinsic activity of the active site; (2) Co-induced phase transition can also reduce the energy required for electron escape, thereby improving the kinetics of the OER process. 5.3.2 Anion doping The intermediate of OER/HER is generally adsorbed on the metal center of the catalytic material. Many studies have found that adjusting the coordination anion of the metal center can enormously raise the intermediate adsorption energy of the catalyst and accelerate the reaction kinetics [309,310]. Chen et al. [311] grew N-Ni3S2 material in situ on the NF substrate through a simple one-step solid-phase reaction and used it as a high-activity bifunctional HER/OER electrocatalyst for the first time. The reasons for the excellent bifunctional activity of N-Ni3S2/NF are deeply revealed: (1) The introduction of anion N significantly increases the DOS near the Fermi level, resulting in higher conductivity, which can promote electron transfer and ultimately improve catalysis activity ((Fig. 17(a) )); (2) The N-Ni3S2/NF electrode has a larger active surface area, which is conducive to obtaining higher electrocatalytic performance((Fig. 17(b))); (3) DFT calculations evidence that the N-modified Ni3S2 material has lower GH* and GH2O*, indicating that H* and H2O* can easily exist on the surface of the N-modified Ni3S2 catalyst, ultimately enhancing the HER activity (Figs. 17(c), (d)). On the basis of this study, Wu et al. [312] demonstrated an effective strategy to improve the H adsorption capacity and HER performance of Ni3S2 through N doping. N-Ni3S2 nanosheets achieve an ultra-low overpotential of 155 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and an excellent exchange current density of 0.42 mA cm−2 in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH electrolyte. These experimental data and theoretical analysis indicate that the increase in catalytic activity is owing to the introduction of new active sites and more effective hydrogen adsorption active bases. There is a close relationship between the HER activity of Ni3S2 surface, the coordination number of surface S atoms and the charge depletion of adjacent Ni atoms. On the stable original Ni3S2 surface, hydrogen adsorption energy is too positive for H* adsorption, and the reduction of surface S coordination number by doping N atoms with higher electronegativity than S may lead to the best H adsorption energy and higher HER efficiency ((Fig. 17(f))). A three-dimensional self-supporting P-doped (Ni, Fe)3S2 nanoarray was created on NF by Liu et al. [313] using a straightforward one-step simultaneous phosphating and vulcanization process. The findings of the study demonstrate that P doping can enhance the ratio of Ni3+/Ni2+ in (Ni, Fe)3S2/NF, resulting in higher OH absorption and essentially boosting the OER activity of (Ni, Fe)3S2/NF (Figs. 17(g), (h)). Additionally, the OER process changes the surface of P-(Ni, Fe)3S2 into the OER's actual active sites, (Ni, Fe)OOH and (Ni, Fe)(OH)2. Alkaline water decomposition can use P-(Ni, Fe)3S2 as an anode and a cathode. It displays a low battery voltage of 1.54 V at 10 mA cm−2 and maintains durability at high current density (100 mA cm−2) at 1 mol L−1 KOH. A large number of low-crystalline ultra-thin nanosheets were added to the surface of the F-Ni3S2 nanoarray electrocatalyst that Xu et al. [314] using a new melting technique. The Ni3S2 nanoarray's surface has undergone extensive rebuilding and a lot of Ni–F bonds have been generated there as a result of fluorination. The production of extremely active NiOOH species and the acceleration of the reaction of the speed determination step (*O → *OOH) are all caused by the Ni–F bonds during the OER process. The optimized F-Ni3S2 has a Tafel slope of 36 mV dec−1 and an overpotential of 239 mV at 10 mA cm−2. To improve the inherent catalytic activity of TMSs, Wu et al. [315] first calculated the H adsorption energy ((Fig. 18(a) )), density of states ((Fig. 18(b))), and charge distribution of doped B atoms in different Fe-S-based electrocatalysts by DFT simulation. The results show that doping B atoms in the Fe7S8/FeS2 electrocatalyst can optimize the d-electronic structure of Fe atoms ((Fig. 18(c))) and the p-electronic structure of S atoms ((Fig. 18(d))). Under the guidance of these theoretical calculations, several B-Fe7S8/FeS2 electrocatalysts were synthesized on carbon cloth ((Fig. 18(e))). The local electronic structure and local electronic structure of the B-Fe7S8/FeS2 electrocatalyst were further characterized at the atomic level. The XAS technique was performed to explore the coordination environment (Figs. 18(f), (g)). When a current density of 10 mA cm−2 is obtained, the HER electrocatalyst exhibits an overpotential of 113 mV in an alkaline medium ((Fig. 18(h))). In addition, B-Fe7S8/FeS2 has a larger electrochemically active surface area ((Fig. 18(i))). Finally, the lowest reaction barrier at the interface of the B-Fe7S8/FeS2 catalyst was determined by calculating the Gibbs free energy of different sites. In conclusion, the enhancement of HER activity of Fe7S8/FeS2 in alkaline media is mainly attributed to the characteristics of B-Fe7S8/FeS2 electrocatalyst with optimized electronic structure, fast electron transfer rate, and low energy barrier of Volmer and Heyrovsky step (Figs. 18(j), (k)). Liu et al. [105] reported the synthesis of S-NiFe2O4 nanosheets on NF by a simple restricted growth strategy with the assistance of thiourea. Due to the exceptional three-dimensional hierarchical structure, the self-supporting electrocatalysts, high conductivity, and fast mass transfer speed, thus having a significant catalytic performance for overall water splitting under alkaline and neutral conditions. Specifically, the best S-NiFe2O4/NF electrode requires only 1.65 and 1.95 V to provide a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH and 1.0 mol L−1 PBS, respectively. 5.3.3 Co-doping Tran et al. [316] used 3D mesoporous cubic CoS2 as the basic catalyst to prepare Co1–x V x SP through vanadium-phosphorus double substitution (Figs. 19(a), (b) ). Corresponding DFT calculations, system studies, and comparisons with control experiments show that the excellent catalytic activity of CoS2 after V doping is mainly attributed to the abundant active sites, and the main role of P substitution is to improve the kinetic performance and the quality of each active site of HER catalyst. Zhang et al. [317] exploited a strategy to simultaneously improve HER activity and durability of CoS2 by manufacturing Fe and P double-doped polycrystalline nanowire (PCW) arrays ((Fig. 19(d))). P substitution significantly improved chemical/mechanical stability and HER dynamics. The PCNW array provides a large specific surface area and allows rapid gas release. The results show that the overpotential of Fe/P-CoS2 PCNW is 80 mV at 10 mA cm−2 ((Fig. 19(c))), and it has excellent durability in an acidic medium. Cao et al. [318] successfully developed a method combining experiment and theory to realize an ultra-efficient rod-shaped MoS2-based alkaline HER electrocatalyst through in-plane structure engineering, heteroatom doping, and phase transition principle. Metal 1T MoS2 nanopatches were synthesized by a simple hydrothermal vulcanization process. These patches were attached to the most exposed catalytic active sites on the surface of SWNT, in which Co atoms and O atoms were bound to the substrate of MoS2, and the electronic structure was changed at the same time. The results show that Co–O 1T-MoS2/SWNT catalyst has low overpotential, low Tafel slope, high stability in alkaline medium, and excellent HER performance. Xu et al. [319] applied NiMoO4 nanowire arrays to prepare N-Ni3S2/N-MoS2 one-dimensional heterogeneous nanowires on NF substrate materials through a chemical conversion strategy. With the in-situ generation of Ni3S2/MoS2 heterogeneous interface and the in-situ introduction of N anions in the nanowires, extraordinary hydrophilicity, a large number of exposed active sites, and the best reaction kinetics for water oxidation and reduction have been obtained. Due to the above advantages, the converted N-Ni3S2/N-MoS2/NF exhibits high-efficiency electrocatalytic activity for both HER and OER under alkaline conditions. Dinh et al. [320] prepared a new type of small core@shell structure CoS x @Cu2MoS4 and MoS2/N, S Co-doped graphene heterogeneous network hybrid (CoS x @Cu2MoS4-MoS2/NSG) through a simple method. It shows excellent performance on ORR, OER, and HER in 1 mol L−1 KOH. The hybrid material exhibits fast ORR kinetics and a high electron transfer number of 3.97 ((Fig. 19(e))), and has exciting durability that is superior to commercial platinum/carbon. It also shows significant stability to HER and OER, and ultimately requires low overpotentials of 118.1 mV (HER) and 351.4 mV (OER) to achieve current densities of 10 mA cm−2, respectively (Figs. 19(f), (g)). Very recently, our research group has also done a work on the modification of transition metal sulfides [321]. Herein, theoretical calculation firstly predicts that metal Ru and S-vacancies can be employed to regulate the electronic structure and adsorption energy of intermediate reactants (Figs. 20(a), (b) ). As shown in (Fig. 20(c)), a facile solvothermal-photochemical strategy was utilized to modulate the NiCo2S4 electrocatalysts: the solvothermal-created S-vacancies in NiCo2S4–x were filled with Ru single atoms under ultraviolet irradiation to obtain the single-atom Ru anchored NiCo2S4–x as OER catalysts; in the same technique, Ru nanoclusters were introduced into NiCo2S4 without S-vacancies for HER (Figs. 20(d)–(g)). The experimental findings show that after decorating NiCo2S4–x with Ru single atoms, the OER exchange current density can be considerably increased. Ru-NiCo2S4–x outperforms most recently reported electrocatalytic materials with its improved HER performance (32 mV@10 mA cm−2) and exceptionally low overpotential of 190 mV at the current density of 50 mA cm−2 for OER (Figs. 20(h), (i)). With a cell voltage of 1.46 V at 10 mA cm−2 in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH, Ru-NiCo2S4–x //Ru-NiCo2S4 also demonstrates excellent stability and catalytic performance in the whole water splitting process (Figs. 20(j), (k)). Bader charge density difference results further unravel the phenomenon of “restricted-delocalized-restricted” behavior between electrons leading to enhanced electron interactions, which in turn improves electrochemical performance. This method paves the way for further exploration and research of late-model electrocatalytic materials in the future. 5.4 Atomic level adjustment In conclusion, modification of transition metal sulfide at the molecular level significantly improves its electrochemical performance and stability. Moreover, some experts design electrocatalysts from the perspective of atoms, which provides an effective way to improve the efficiency of atomic use and reduce economic costs [322]. Among them, single-atom catalysts have attracted widespread attention mainly due to their extremely high specific activity and significant atom utilization efficiency. The electrochemical activity of a single-atom site is highly dependent on its inherent chemical and physical properties. Specifically, the single-atom microenvironment, including the geometric structure and electronic coordination, plays an extremely important role in improving the performance of the catalyst [323]. Therefore, it is imperative to explore and understand the structure-activity relationship of single atoms from the aspects of material synthesis and reaction mechanism. 5.4.1 Single-atom adjustment Zhou et al. [324] firstly explored the local electron interaction of Ni position in the Ni3S2 system by introducing Pt into the system through theoretical calculation. As shown in Figs. 21(a), and (b) the redistribution of electrons in the formed new system will affect part of the density of states. Compared with the Ni3S2 system, the total DOS of the monoatomic Pt anchored Ni3S2 shows a higher electronic occupied state near the Fermi level, resulting in a higher intrinsic conductivity and a greater carrier concentration. Therefore, based on the above-mentioned analysis and optimization of the electronic structure of PtSA-Ni3S2, its potential HER activity was predicted. Supported by the DFT calculation results, the corresponding PtSA-Ni3S2 material was designed on the carbon cloth by a simple in-situ electrodeposition method ((Fig. 21(d))), which has a large number of exposed Ni vacancies generated by the interaction between Cl− and functional groups on the Ni3S2 surface to anchor the atom dispersed Pt, showing an ultra-low overpotential in HER (31 mV@10 mA cm−2) ((Fig. 21(c))). Furthermore, FT-EXAFS of Pt shows that Pt is anchored in monatomic form and forms a coordination structure with the nearest three S atoms in the basic catalyst ((Fig. 21(e))). HAADF also further demonstrated the successful synthesis of the target catalyst PtSA-Ni3S2 ((Fig. 21(f))). Similarly, Wang et al. [325] preliminarily determined the influence of introducing S vacancy in MoS2 on electron density near Fermi level through theoretical calculation ((Fig. 21(g))), and then successfully synthesized atom Mo-MoS2 on carbon cloth by simple hydrothermal method and electrochemical etching method. The existence of S vacancy can be found in (Fig. 21(i)), and it can also be found in the EPR examination that S vacancy concentration changes significantly with the increase of etching time. The obtained MoS2-60s sample showed ultra-low overpotential (131 mV@10 mA cm−2) and excellent stability in HER (Figs. 21(k), (l)). The fusion of metal single atoms into nanostructures is a new method to stimulate rich active centers. Hoa et al. [326] prepared the basic catalyst on the highly conductive substrate tin by using a simple continuous vulcanized MoC2 heterojunction, and successfully anchored the single atom Ru to obtain the three-dimensional layered porous material Ru-MoS2-Mo2C/TiN (Figs. 22(a), (b) ). Based on the current density of 10 mA cm−2, an overpotential of 25 mV (HER), 280 mV (OER), and a battery voltage of 1.49 V (OW) are required respectively (Figs. 22(c)–(e)). In addition, the theoretical calculation further proves the reasonable density of states near the Fermi level and the optimal adsorption free energy of the reactant ((Fig. 22(f))). Not only that, Lee et al. [327] grew a bifunctional electrocatalyst based on monoatomic Co modified MoS2 nanosheets on a three-dimensional TiN nanorod array for the overall water splitting of pH-universal electrolytes. ((Fig. 22(g))). When CoSAs-MoS2/TiN NRs are used as independent cathode electrodes, their overpotentials are 187.5, 131.9, and 203.4 mV under acidic, alkaline, and neutral conditions, respectively, reaching an HER current density of 10 mA cm−2. Under the same current density, it is superior to most non-noble metal HER electrocatalysts reported in the past. Co atom dispersion can achieve maximum atom exposure and can significantly increase the density of Co containing active sites. Importantly, the strong interaction between CoSAs and layered MoS2 regulates the electron density distribution of Co and MoS2, provides more catalytically active sites for reactant molecules, and optimizes the adsorption of intermediates in the water electrolysis process (Figs. 22(h), (i)). In addition, the CoSAs-MoS2/TiN NRs catalyst has a large specific surface area and typical mesoporous properties. The unique three-dimensional core/shell structure combined with the mesoporous structure provides a large specific surface area and a large number of active sites. Thereby, the contact surface between the reactant and the active site is enlarged, and the permeation/diffusion of the reactant and the release of gas are promoted. The obtained CoSAs-MoS2/TiN also showed ultra-low battery voltage (1.68 V@10 mA cm−2) and excellent stability in the dual-motor system (Figs. 22(1), (m)). 5.4.2 Dual single-atom adjustment Single-atom catalysts show well-defined active sites and potential maximum atom utilization. Correspondingly, double single atoms (DACs) not only have the 100% site utilization rate of SACs but also can overcome some limitations of SACs in the multi-electron reaction with various reaction intermediates. Therefore, the effect of DACs research has received increasing attention due to its obvious advantages over SACs. For example, the two metal centers in DACs can provide two sites for the binding of reactants in the three-dimensional geometric structure, so that the independent binding energy of the ideal HER/OER catalyst can be predicted. Although DACs have higher electrocatalytic activity than SACs, their controlled synthesis is difficult to achieve. So far, DAC production methods include high-temperature pyrolysis, deposition technology, and wet-chemical methods. Bai et al. [328] reported that it is feasible to prepare monatomic precatalysts containing Co, Fe, and Ni by in situ transformation. The structures of the catalysts were characterized by XAS and HAADF analysis. The molecular bimetallic active sites of these supported catalysts were revealed. For each catalyst, cycling catalytic experiments exhibit a bimetallic coordination environment and follow similar O–O bond formation steps. Wang and his colleagues [329] first proposed an approach for adjacent DACs in a heterogeneous plane, that is, using a bimetallic MOF containing Zn and Co similar to ZIF-8 to coat FeCl3 molecules by a two-solvent method, as shown in the (Fig. 23(a) ). According to HAADF-STEM ((Fig. 23(b))) and the measurement results EXAFS before and after the electrochemical test, the relatively volatile Zn is proposed to be vaporized and replaced by Fe ions to form Fe-Co DAC. In the subsequent work, Wang et al. [330] modified the synthesis of Fe-Co DAC by using carbon nanotubes. At the same time, Ye et al. [331] were able to encapsulate Fe(Co)2, Fe2(Co)9, or Fe3(Co)12 precursors in the ZIF-8 cavity in situ (Figs. 23(c), (d)). Subsequent pyrolysis and evaporation of Zn caused Fe clusters to attach to the N-doped carbon, forming Fe1-N/C, Fe2-N/C, or Fe3-N/C sites. The disadvantage of this Modification process is that the prepared Fe metal content is relatively low. There are many examples applications of the function of ZIF (ZIF-8, ZIF-67) to generate adjacent DACs in the plane for electrochemical reactions. 5.5 Extra-electric-field engineering Different from complex nanostructures, some reports have found that the OER performance of magnetic catalysts is closely related to its spin configuration. During the four-electron reaction, the number of unpaired electrons cannot be conserved, resulting in spin-related catalytic activity [332,333]. Zhou et al. [334] proposed a simple magnetic simulation method to realize spin-flip and reconstruction near the active site through the coordination mechanism between local magnetocaloric effect and spin-exchange interaction, and finally obtained unprecedented OER performance. In this work, bimetallic Co0.8Mn0.2-MOF materials were prepared as a thermal differential spintronic catalyst, in which magnetic heating was periodically distributed to strengthen the spin-orbit interaction and drive the desired spin reconstruction. As shown in (Fig. 24(a) ), when these metal atoms are exposed on the surface to act as reaction sites, the catalytic activity will be significantly enhanced because the unpaired 3d orbitals accept the lone pair of electrons from the adsorbed intermediate. As a result, the orbital interaction between the metal active site and the intermediate (*OH) also changes accordingly, as shown in (Fig. 24(c)). In this process, the t2g orbital of the unfilled catalytic site is more likely to accept the valence electrons of the reactant, which is more conducive to the adsorption of *OH for the OER cycle. In other words, the spin-dependent OER process can be optimized by spin reconstruction, and the constructed MOF is shown in (Fig. 24(e)). The charge density between the rise and fall of the spin is symmetrically distributed in the interlayer region. To verify this feasibility, the DFT is combined with finite element numerical simulation to theoretically predict the magnetic heating and heat conduction processes in the system, as shown in (Fig. 24(f)). At the same time, Co0.8Mn0.2-MS-20 min showed excellent performance in OER (Fig. 24(d,g)). A ferromagnetic ordered catalyst was used by Ren et al. [335] as a spin polarizer for spin selection in a magnetic field that was kept constant. The result was a variety of catalytic materials. OER measurements on CoFe2O4 were carried out at various temperatures, as illustrated in (Fig. 24(h)). They first detected a considerable rise in the catalyst's OER performance as the reaction temperature rose. This could be as a result of the fact that an increase in reaction temperature will result in a faster reaction rate constant. There will be reduced electron-electron repulsion during the major FM exchange between the ferromagnetic catalyst and the oxygen species that have been adsorbed ((Fig. 24(i))), which results in spin-related conductivity and a decrease in the rate-limiting binding energy. 6 Potential applications Due to their distinct internal structure, transition metal sulfides are frequently used in supercapacitors, CO2 photoreduction, electroreduction, lithium ion batteries, and other areas in addition to electrocatalytic overall water splitting. For instance, Kang et al. [336] used atomic-level defect engineering to incorporate P dopants and S vacancies on the surface of NiCo2S4 nanotubes to enhance charge storage kinetics (P-NiCo2S4–x ). The high specific capacity of 1806.4 C g−1 at 1 A g−1 of the as-prepared P-NiCo2S4–x . NiTi2S4 was created by Kim et al. [337] using a straightforward, high-energy mechanical ball milling process, and its electrochemical characteristics were examined. It has better cycling performance, with a reversible capacity of 635 mAh g−1 after 50 cycles at a current density of 1000 mA g−1. Shi et al. [338] optimally graded MoS2 composites not only have a significantly improved specific surface area and electronic conductivity, but also have a better capacity to adsorb CO2, which leads to a notable improvement in the overall Faradaic efficiency. 7 Conclusions and perspectives 7.1 Conclusions Electrocatalytic overall water splitting to produce hydrogen has attracted the attention of more and more research experts in recent years because of its advantages such as non-polluting products, high purity of hydrogen, and simple equipment. It has also carried out in-depth exploration on the internal mechanism of electrocatalysts, including metal sulfides, and achieved significant results. The accurate understanding of the OER/HER process has provided theoretical support for our subsequent design and research of commercial catalysts to a certain extent. In general, we have summarized the current research status of transition metal sulfide-based catalysts and further confirmed their great potential as non-noble metal catalysts to replace commercial catalysts Pt, RuO2, and IrO2. The preparation methods of transition metal sulfides: hydrothermal, solvothermal, chemical vapor deposition, stripping, ball milling, and so on are reviewed. In addition, it is introduced that under the guidance of these methods, some modification methods such as compounding, introducing defects, vacancies, morphology regulation can be adjusted to the electronic structure, increase the number of active sites, optimize the adsorption/or desorption energy of reaction intermediates, and reduce the reaction energy barrier of the OER process, resulting in excellent electrochemistry performance of single metal sulfide and multi-metal sulfide. Finally, some typical research results reveal the esoteric principle of the structure-composition-pro- perty changes of TMSs in the process of overall water splitting. When more metals are added, the electronic structure and the coordination environment close to the active center will alter somewhat, especially in the case of polymetallic sulfide where the active site may be a metal cation. For the substance to function more effectively as a catalyst, it might potentially be a mixture of several metals. However, it is emphasized that although TMSs have achieved excellent catalytic performance in OER/HER process, the exact understanding of the OER/HER reaction mechanism of bimetallic sulfides is still in the preliminary stage of exploration, and the following challenges need to be overcome before large-scale commercial application is possible in the future. Fig. 25 An overview of transition metal sulfides. 7.2 Perspectives 7.2.1 Improving characterization methods and advocating in-situ characterization technology Since non-in-situ characterisation technology has only been developed recently, the majority of research specialists have focused on the structural alteration of the catalyst (such as basic composition, elemental valence state, material morphology and so on). The reaction mechanism at the atomic level that results in the surface reconstruction during the OER/HER process is still not obvious in the text and requires more in-depth study. In terms of HER, the mechanism in an alkaline electrolyte is entirely distinct from one in an acidic medium, where hydrogen bonding is the only factor involved. The HER process in alkaline media is more intricate and involves OH* poisoning of the electrocatalyst surface along with the adsorption and dissociation of water molecules, hydrogen adsorption and desorption, and even hydrogen adsorption and desorption. OER illustrates this particularly well. Therefore, it is very necessary to actively develop some in-situ characterization technologies, such as in-situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy, in-situ environmental pressure XPS, in-situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy, and in-situ Raman spectroscopy, to monitor the dynamic evolution of intermediates, the dynamic changes of electronic structure and identify real reactive substances (such as structural reorganization during OER, reaction paths followed by HER and so on). 7.2.2 Enhancing dynamic calculation and ensuring the accuracy of the calculation model From the development status of overall water spitting, the electrocatalytic reaction mechanism has not been revealed clearly, which is mainly owing to the limitation of dynamic calculation, the inability to apply voltage, temperature change, and other factors in the calculation process. In the future, we need to explore more flexible ideas and perfect theoretical systems to systematically and deeply study the real active sites, electrode-electrolyte interface characteristics, conversion of surface hydroxyl oxides during OER catalyst reaction, HER reaction mechanism, structural conversion in the electrochemical reaction, etc. In addition, the combination of theoretical calculation with advanced experimental characterization techniques, continuous revision of theoretical model, and tracking of the entire reaction process can provide a deeper understanding of HER and OER mechanisms. 7.2.3 Devoting to efficient overall water splitting performance under a high current density It is worth pointing out that overall water splitting under industrial conditions needs to be carried out under high current density. Compared with current density < 10 mA cm−2, a higher bias voltage is required to reach OER, which will cause a more serious polarization phenomenon. Secondly, the electrochemical reaction of OER is more intense, which will consume reactants and generate products at a higher rate. This requires our research experts to pay attention to the continuous increase of current density when developing catalysts in the future to ensure that the commercial application goals. 7.2.4 Attaching importance to the stability of sulfides Existing in-situ characterization techniques and theoretical calculations have preliminarily confirmed that sulfides will inevitably be converted to oxyhydroxides in electrochemical examinations, which has hindered the further improvement of sulfide stability. Therefore, in the future modification process, it should be combined with (1) and (2) to further optimize the stability of the material under the premise of in-situ monitoring to realize commercial standards. 7.2.5 Establishing a unified evaluation standard The catalytic performance should be compared under uniform standard conditions, which is conducive to the selection and optimization of existing systems and the feasibility evaluation of newly developed electrocatalysts. At present, the evaluation criteria of electrocatalytic performance are distinct in different studies due to the differences in catalyst support, mass load, reaction conditions, preparation methods, electrode areas, test conditions, iR compensation, and substrate effect. Therefore, researchers should be actively encouraged to examine the Faraday efficiency, overpotential, mass load, exchange current density, and Tafel slope of catalysts under standard conditions to accurately assess the activity of future novel catalysts. For instance, the same powder material, same substrate material, and similar IR compensation material should all be categorized and compared in the process of evaluating basic electrochemical activity. 7.2.6 Attempting a temperate electrolyte and paving the foundation for commercial applications Most bifunctional electrocatalysts reported at present are conducted under alkaline conditions, and few are discussed under neutral conditions, which is mainly due to the unsatisfactory electrochemical activity, corrosion resistance, and stability of current electrocatalysts under neutral conditions, which is different from the actual commercial standards. Therefore, it is necessary to continuously develop and explore appropriate new catalytic materials to ensure their wide application in near-neutral medium and seawater. Fig. 26 A summary of the development of transition metal sulfides. 7.2.7 Pay attention to the recovery of catalysts and realizing the importance of protecting the environment Since most transition metal sulfides involve hydrochloric acid, thioacetamide, thiourea, sulfur powder, and other environmentally unfriendly materials in the preparation process, attention should be paid to the following aspects: recovery of catalyst, improvement of the recovery system, desorption of catalytic materials. Pay attention to protecting the environment. In addition, more new pollution-free catalytic materials should be developed actively. Conflicts of interest The authors declare no conflict of interest. Lei Ge (College of New Energy and Materials, China University of Petroleum Beijing) received his B.S. in 2002 and Ph.D degree in 2006 from Tianjin University. At the end of 2006, he joined the faculty of Department of Materials Science and Engineering, China University of Petroleum Beijing. From 2011 to 2012, he did postdoctoral research at The University of California at Riverside. His research interests currently focus on new materials and energy photocatalysis, electrocatalysis with emphasis on design of new catalysts and control of morphology, microstructure and reaction mechanism for hydrogen production, environmental pollutants degradation, etc. Some of his recent progresses include the novel approaches to design cocatalysts decorated photocatalysts with controllable microstructures, the synthesis of novel hollow structured materials with superior catalytic performance, preparation of metal and nonmetal ions doped electrocatalysts derived from MOFs with high overwall water splitting performance. He has coauthored more than 120 peer-reviewed papers. He was invited as a young member of the editorial board of Chin. J. Catal. Since 2020.

coredata.dc:description: Electrochemical hydrogen evolution via water splitting has been regarded as a highly promising technique for fossil-fuel substitution in the future to avoid environmental pollution and energy waste. As half of the water splitting reaction, the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is the major obstacle because of the sluggish kinetics of the complex reaction. It is imperative and urgent to develop highly efficient, low cost and earth-abundant electrocatalysts to overcome the sluggish kinetics issue. Among the various non-noble-metal-based electrocatalysts, transition metal chalcogenide (TMS) associated materials have been exploited as potential candidates for the past few years due to their excellent electrochemical performance and unique internal structure. In this review, we have summarized the recent advances of transition metal sulfides (TMSs) for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), OER, and overall water splitting, then we have reviewed several modified strategies from the perspective of their functional concepts to synthesis methods, characterization techniques, catalytic mechanisms and performances. Finally, the existing deficiencies, challenges and future development directions of TMSs in OER, HER, and overall water splitting process are further discussed and summarized.

coredata.dc:title: Recent progress on design and applications of transition metal chalcogenide-associated electrocatalysts for the overall water splitting
